name: Golden Gate Campground
description: GOLDEN GATE CAMPGROUND (Campground)

name: MYRTLE GROVE
description: This site provides primitive campsites along the South Fork of the Coquille River. ; Facilities5 campsites with picnic tables, and fire pitsNo drinking waterVault toiletGarbage Disposal Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day weekend

name: HARR POINT CAMPGROUND
description: Campground is on the east shore of Applegate Lake and is accessible only by the Payette Trail #970; or by boat. Persons accessing this site by boat may find current information about lake levels helpful. This is a semi-primitive site. Facilities 5 campsites (tent-sites) with picnic tables, and fire pits. No drinking water. Vault toilets available. No garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: BIG SPRING
description: This campground is located in an open ponderosa pine forest and along a babbling creek. The campsites vary in size significantly to accommodate many different group sizes.

name: Roxie Peconom
description: Campground located 2 miles off highway 36. There are 10 walk in sites, hand pumped water and vault toilet.

name: WILDHORSE
description: This site offers solitude with scenic views of the mountainous areas of the Rogue River - Siskiyou National Forest, including glorious starry nights and high mountain breezes during the hot days of summer.Facilities3 campsites with picnic tables and fire pitsNo campground hostNo drinking waterPit toiletNo garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: Canyon Creek Cg
description: Canyon Creek Campground is located on Canyon Creek in a mixed conifer forest, near Faucherie Reservoir. It is a remotecampground with 20 campsites, vault toilets,bear proof food lockers,paved parking,and no trash service (pack it in, pack it out.)The road to the campground is very rough, rocky, and narrow, requiring high clearance; towing/trailers not recommended.

name: Sulphur Springs Trail Camp
description: SULPHUR SPRINGS Trail Camp

name: Barnhouse
description: This campground is surprisingly quiet and serene as it sits nestled among some large ponderosa pine trees just a few miles from the main highway. It also hosts the trailhead for Barnhouse Trail (#813) located in the northwest corner of the campground.  This is a great location to camp in the pines and explore the National Park units in the John Day Fossil Bed National Monument.

name: Cassidy Bridge
description: The Cassidy Bridge Hunt Camp is located in a nicely wooded area along the banks of the Chauga River, one of the popular fishing streams on the district. During big-game and turkey hunting seasons, the campground is opened free of charge. During the rest of the year, the camp is available by reservation.

name: Kawishiwi Lake Cg
description: Kawishiwi Lake is a lovely 5 site campground in a birch stand on the edge of the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness.  It provides an excellent campsite for people entering or exiting the BWCAW via the Kawishiwi Lake Entry Point.  The BWCAW boundary is the shore of the lake, so motors are not allowed on the lake and if you plan on putting a canoe in the water at all, you will need a day use permit available at a kiosk at the access point.  There are no electrical hook-ups or potable water available on-site and users must pack in and pack out their garbage as there are no garbage services on-site

name: Airplane Flat
description: Airplane Flat campground is in an open stand of mature Ponderosa pine. Canyon Creek is known for its trout fishing. Wildlife includes: Abert squirrel, black bear, mountain lion, elk, turkey and deer. Pack it in & Pack it out, no trash services. 14-day stay limit. Trailers must be under 16 feet.

name: Harriet Lake Rustic Campground
description: Harriet Lake Rustic Campground is located at the site of an abandoned farm.  There are 9 campsites located in the campground and the open land around these sites now hosts a variety of coneflowers and other plants not common in a boreal forest.  It also provides opportunities for group picnicking.  The lake itself is accessed by a boat ramp and dock and supports walleye, northern pike, and crappies.  There is no garbage pick up at Harriet Lake Rustic Campground.  Plan to pack out all your garbage, including fish remains from cleaning fish.

name: Hovey Lake Camping Area
description: HOVEY LAKE CAMPING AREA (Campground)

name: BAKER LAKE RUSTIC CAMPGROUND
description: Baker Lake Rustic Campground is a 5 site campground located in a stand of red pine on the shore of Baker Lake.  Unlike most other rustic campgrounds, there is a solar powered faucet for drinking water.  It is an excellent first or last night site for people who are using the Baker Lake Entry Point to the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness.  All sites are first come/ first served and there is no electricity at this campground.  All sites are better suited to tent camping as opposed to RVs.  There is no garbage pick up at Baker Lake Rustic Campground.  Plan to pack out all your garbage, including fish remains from cleaning fish.

name: Sapillo
description: SAPILLO (Group Campground)

name: PANTHER MEADOWS CG
description: This is a walk-in campground is located near timberline on Mt. Shasta at 7500 feet. There are 15 sites, all within a short walk of your vehicle.  There are tables, fire-rings, and vault toilets. Bring your own water or purify the creek water nearby. 3 day limit, per person, per year. No fee. No reservations. Self-register on site. Usually opens around July 1st, depending on winter snowpack, and closes November 1st. Features: Highest campground on the mountain with open views and vistas. There are two small sub-alpine heather meadows a short distance from the campground. Because of the fragile nature of the meadows, great care must be given by all who visit not to incur damage. In recent years, a major effort has been made by local tribes, volunteers, and the Forest Service to re-vegetate the native species and improve the trail system to minimize erosion.

name: EDEN VALLEY
description: Sites are along the Glendale-Powers Bicycle Recreation Area, a beautiful way to experience the many waterfalls and sweeping scenery this part of southern Oregon has to offer!; Facilities11 campsites with picnic tables, and fire pitsNo drinking water2 vault toiletsNo garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: Hickory Nut Mountain
description: Day use area with picnic tables, grills and fire rings

name: REYNOLDS SHELTER
description: Reynold Shelter Camping Area is located on the northwest corner of the Boulder Creek Wilderness Area. The Reynolds Shelter was rebuilt in 2022, after it was burned down due to human error. The shelter is located on the south side of the road. There are no garbage services at this camping site, please be prepared to pack out your trash.

name: Toohey Lake Rustic Campground
description: Toohey Lake Rustic Campground is a seven site campground with a boat launch and trailer parking.  It is right off of a well traveled forest road, making for easy access.  Ride-in and ride-out OHV opportunities are available in this campground.  There is no garbage pick up at Toohey Lake Rustic Campground.  Plan to pack out all your garbage, including fish remains from cleaning fish.

name: COLCORD RIDGE
description:
Situated within a mixed forest of Ponderosa pine, white and Douglas fir, Colcord Ridge is a great place to go during the hot summer months. Trout fishing is available -- 5 miles to the east of Canyon Creek Canyon Creek Fish Hatchery -- 5 miles east on FR 33. Wildlife includes black bear, elk, mountain lion, javelina and deer. This site is a great camp site for youth first learning how to camp. 

Pack it in & Pack it out, no trash services.

name: Spruce Grove
description: 7 hike-in campsites, picnic tables and klamath stoves, vault toilets, no trash receptacles, no piped water available. Seasonal stream water (treat before using). However, water flow may be low or non-existent due to reduced rainfall. Please bring enough water for cooking, cleaning, drinking, and extinguishing campfires. Pack In-Pack Out.

name: HONEY HILL
description: This primitive camping facility is located between McClellanville and Honey Hill. A short camp loop swings through an upland pine/oak forest and encircles a fire lookout tower. The fire lookout tower is no longer in use.

name: Frog Heaven Forest Camp
description: No facilities are provided nor is this area maintained. It is truly for the camper wanting to rough it. Check with La Grande Ranger District office for more ponds to fish in the Blue Mountains.

name: Cascade River Cg
description: Cascade River Rustic Campground is a small camping area particularly suited to people who are planning to fish in the Cascade River or are looking for a remote place to camp.  This campground has four campsites and a vault toilet.  No potable water is available on-site.  Fishing requires a valid license from the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources, and trout fishing requires an additional stamp.

name: Morrison Creek Cg
description: This site was burned over in the Cascade Creek Fire of 2012. Several primitive camp sites are available, some along Morrison Creek. The site serves as a trailhead to the Shorthorn Trail #16 which enters Mount Adams Wilderness and is within 3 miles of the popular South Climb #183 Trail and route up Mt Adams. A wilderness permit is required to enter the wilderness. Permits are free and self-issued at the trailhead. Motorized and mechanized uses are not allowed in Wilderness areas. Road access is rough and not recommended for trailers or motor homes.

name: LAIRD LAKE
description: Sites are located on the Wild and Scenic Elk River, and along the Wild Rivers Coast Scenic Bikeway!Facilities4 campsites with picnic tables, and fire pitsNo drinking waterVault toiletNo garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: Upper Peppermint
description: 7100-foot elevation. Undeveloped dispersed camping area within the Giant Sequoia National Monument. Fishing available in nearby Peppermint creek, check with the Department of Fish and Wildlife for regulations. No services, no fee. Dispersed Camping Rules, Regulations, and Tips

name: LOWER BUCK CREEK
description: Lower Buck Creek is located approximately 30 minutes southwest of Silver Lake, Oregon. For back-country solitude, look no further than Lower Buck Creek. This small, secluded campground is located in a small valley adjacent to Buck Creek, nestled next to a riparian meadow. This campground has five camping sites, picnic tables, fire rings, and one vault toilet. The meadow, and access to the creek is accessed through a small gate next to the vault toilet. Lower Buck Creek is ideal for wildlife viewing (deer and elk), photography, and relaxing. You can also fish for trout in the creek and stroll along the perennial stream that flows from Yamsay Mountain. There is no; potable water. Visitors need to pack plenty of water, and pack in and out any refuse.

name: LAGUNITAS
description: 12 campsites at 10,400 '||chr(39)||' in Upper and Lower Lagunitas areas are adjacent to breath-taking Cruces Basin.

name: BIG CREEK CAMPGROUND
description: Generally open May to October, as weather and conditions allow. Access to Kingston Canyon and Groves Lake. High clearance vehicle needed. Surrounded by water birch, cottonwood, and Russian olive trees at the mouth of a canyon along a creek. Stream runs through the campground.

name: NF CATHERINE CREEK CAMPGROUND
description: The North Fork Catherine Creek Campground is a unique facility since the campsites are spread out for over 1 mile beginning at the Buck Creek road up to the North Fork Catherine Creek Trailhead. Each campsite is set back in the cool evergreen forest and is a popular area in the summer months for those wanting to escape the heat, enjoy the sounds of the stream, view wildlife, or take a short hike along the creek.  Also located nearby is the North Fork Catherine Creek Group Campground, that is available on Rec.gov for $40/night.

name: THREE SISTERS
description: The Three Sisters Overlook Campsite is a fully accessible, single occupancy site on the Nemo Loop Road (6267) on Wrangell Island. Site overlooks Zimovia Strait, with spectacular views of the three sister peaks (Virginia, Bessie, and Helen) on Etolin Island.

name: Walnut Flats
description: This small, primitive campground is well suited for tent camping but also accommodates small recreation vehicles. It has shaded sites clustered around a grassy opening surrounded by forest. Flat Top Mountain Trail System, the Appalachian Trail, Dismal Creek (a stocked trout stream), and the Falls of Dismal are close by.

name: Ice Hole Campground
description: ICE HOLE CAMPGROUND (Campground)

name: Wrangle Campground
description: There are several picnic tables and a rustic shelter built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in 1936, and a cabin built by the Soil Conservation Service, also in the 1930s. There is a community kitchen available. Facilities 5 campsites (tent-sites) with picnic tables, and fire pits. No drinking water. Vault toilet available. No garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: Green Creek Camping Area
description: Green Creek Camping Area is approximately 26 miles northwest of Dubois, Wyoming, and is located roughly 9.4 miles northwest of Union Pass Road which connects to the communities of Cora and Pinedale, Wyoming. Union Pass Road winds through the northern Wind River and eastern Gros Ventres Mountains which are maged by the Shoshone and Bridger-Teton tiol Forests.  Highly acclaimed hiking trails, most notably the Continental Divide tiol Scenic Trail, are located within proximity to the campground which accesses the renowned back country areas of the Fitzpatrick Wilderness, and numerous motorized touring routes for people that wish to explore the Wind River's front country.   Green Creek Camping Area is popular during fall hunting seasons for dispersed camping, and is near for motorized trail opportunities. Food and bear attractants must be stored in accord with the Shoshone tiol Forest Food Storage Order. The camping area has a capacity of up to 50 people, 7 bear boxes, ample parking, a vault toilet, and visitor information. There is a 16-day stay limit.

name: Harris Trailhead / Horse Camp
description: HARRIS TRAILHEAD / HORSE CAMP (Horse Camp)

name: Upper Shake
description: Closed Campground.

name: Lower Black Canyon
description: LOWER BLACK CANYON (Campground)

name: Woodchuck - Cg
description: Woodchuck Campground is located on Rattlesnake Creek in a remote location. Campground is surrounded by a mixed conifer forest.

name: FRENCHY POINT
description: Located on Bullards Bar Reservoir, boat in only access. It is used as an over flow campground. There are campsites, but no bathrooms.

name: Big Springs Campground
description: Located between Mammoth Lakes and June Lake, near the Crestview area, this campground has 26 campsites surrounded by pine forest. This is a popular basecamp for fishing Deadman Creek, exploring Obsidian Dome and OHV/ATV trails in the Lookout Mountain area. Bring your own water. Sites are self register when you arrive, no reservations.14 day stay limit.

name: BOGARD
description: Quiet and tucked away from the beaten path. Pine creek adjacent to campground, beautiful aspens in and around campground. Located 1.75 miles off Highway 44. No Fees. 10 sites. Hand pumped water. Vault toilets, Maximum trailer length 25 feet.

name: Yunshookuh Loop Campsite
description: The Yunshookuh Loop Campsite is a fully accessible campground with options for RV or tent camping (no hookups). Space for three groups, with shared outhouse between sites. A 12?x 16? covered picnic shelter is located at the middle site. The site provides for scenic views of Zimovia Straight. Site is popular for winter sledding on roadway when snow limits access to ATV, snow machine, or skis/snowshoes.

name: WILDWOOD
description: This small rustic campground is located; east of the 2,035-acre Ochoco Divide Research and Natural Area. It is forested with ponderosa pine, western larch, Douglas-fir, and grand fir. It has easy access from Highway 26, and is seldom crowded so it makes for a quiet and peaceful getaway.

name: WOLF CREEK INDUSTRIAL
description: This site is adjacent to Wolf Creek Campground.  Fees are collected at Wolf Creek Campground.

name: SRU LAKE
description: Campsites are located in a mountain lake setting. ; This site is also close to the Coquille River Falls Research Natural Area. Facilities6 campsites with picnic tables, and fire pitsFishing platformNo drinking waterVault toiletNo garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: ALLEN CREEK HORSE CAMP
description: Located south of Bridge Creek Wilderness, Allen Creek Horse Camp sits among large ponderosa pine trees and along the creek that feeds Allen Creek Reservoir. There are five campsites which are currently maintained and several corrals on site. There are no manure pits at this campground so the Forest Service requests that you pack out waste from your horses. There is no water system at the camp, but a stream borders the east side of the camp from which you can water your animals. Allen Creek Reservoir is very close to the campground, though it cannot be accessed directly from the site; instead it can be accessed through BLM land just a few miles away. Learn about Leave No Trace principles of horse camping.  View a map; of the Allen Creek equestrian trails.

name: MARINER'S ROOST CG-F
description: Mariners Roost is a boat access only campground located on the Est Fork Stuart Fork Arm of Trinity Lake on the east side of Mule Creek cove. The campground offers 7 campsites with vault toilets.

name: GRASSY FLATS
description: Dispersed campsites in large meadow.  Heavily used during hunting season.Facilities 5 camp sites; No drinking waterNo toiletNo garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: Redfish Inlet Cg
description: Redfish Lake Inlet is accessible either through water access: shuttle boat, kayak, canoe or hiking in. The campground consists of 4 sites and is first-come, first-serve. This site has trash removal and toilets but no potable water. It is located at the very southern end of Redfish lake by the Redfish Inlet trailhead. Enjoy hiking Redfish trail along Mt. Heyburn, Braxon Peak, Grand Mogul and Decker Peak near the Bench lakes and Saddle back lakes in the beautiful Sawtooth Wilderness area. Enjoy hiking, swimming, fishing and kayaking from this unique location.

name: Scotts Camp
description: Located to the north of Big Summit Prairie and to the south of Bridge Creek Wilderness, Scotts Campground is a great hub for your forest adventure. Conveniently located at the junction of Forest Service Road 22, Forest Service Road 3010, and Forest Service Road 2630, this campground provides easy access to many kinds of recreational activities.

name: PLANTATION FLATS CAMPING AREA
description: Dispersed Camping Area. Facilities include vault toilet in the area.

name: Valentine Ridge
description: A dispersed camping area situated near Canyon Creek, known for its rainbow trout fishing.  A 9-mile all-terrain bicycle loop trail starts at the camping area. Wildlife includes: Abert squirrel, black bear, mountain lion, elk, turkey and deer. Arizona Game & Fish Department Canyon Creek Fish Hatchery is nearby.

name: DOUBLE CABIN
description: Nestled among the big pines near the heart of the Maury Mountains this isolated campground is the perfect get away from busy civilization. ; Though there are few recreational activities branching directly from the campground, Double Cabin Pond is just a short walk away, and Antelope Flat Reservoir is just a short drive from the campground.

name: S-Tree Campground
description: S-Tree Campground sits on a ridge above Horse Lick Creek near McKee in Jackson County, Kentucky. Each of the 20 first-come, first-served campsites has a picnic table, tent pad, fire ring and lantern pole. The campground's small first come, first served picnic area features a historic shelter that was constructed in the 1930s by the Civilian Conservation Corps. The campground is popular with off-highway vehicle (OHV) enthusiasts due to its proximity to Renfro Loop OHV Trail #302. The campground cannot accommodate trailers longer than 25 feet due to one lane roads and no turn-outs.

name: Tipsu Tyee Campground
description: Tipsu Tyee is located along the shore of Applegate Lake and is accessible only by the Payette Trail #970; or by boat. Persons accessing this site by boat may find current information about lake levels helpful. Facilities5 campsites (tent-sites) with picnic tables, and fire pits. No drinking water. Vault toilets available. No garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: Ball Club Lake Site 1
description: BALL CLUB LAKE Site 1 (Camping Area)- backcountry dispersed site on the north shore of Ball Club Lake

name: Spring Camp
description: Closed due to the Bobcat Fire. Elevation: 4700-Foot Elevation Amenities: 3 OHV/Hike-in campsites- picnic tables, vault toilets, no fire appliances, no trash receptacles, no piped water available. Seasonal stream water (treat before using). However, water flow may be low or non-existent due to reduced rainfall. Please bring enough water for cooking, cleaning, drinking, and extinguishing campfires. Pack In-Pack Out. OHV: Located along Rincon-Shortcut OHV Route. Permit needed for use of this route. Equestrian: Hitching Rails Fees: Camping - Adventure Pass/America the Beautiful Pass Required.

name: Madrone Cg-F
description: This campground has 10 Sites and can accommodate Trailer up to 16'.  The site has picnic tables, vault toilets, and parking.  Tis pack-it-in pack-it-out campground is first come first served.

name: Oronoco
description: Located near Vesuvius, VA, this spot is a favorite among campers looking for a primitive, no-frills experience.

name: Red Cloud -New
description: RED CLOUD -NEW (Campground)

name: Philpot Cg-F
description: This facility has 6 picnic spots and vault toilets.  There is no water system and the access to the facility is unpaved. The facility provides hiking access for the Philpot Interpretive Trail.

name: Sam'S Throne
description: Primarily well known as a rock climbing site, Sam's Throne, near Mt. Judea, is also a popular hiking, camping and photography destination. Located up on Judea Mountain and overlooking the Big Creek valley below, the scenic views will show you why this is such a popular place. This is a dispersed camping area with no trash services. Pack it in, pack it out

name: Third Bridge Campsites
description: THIRD BRIDGE CAMPSITES (Camping Area)

name: Luther Pass Overflow Campground
description: Low development scale Forest Service operated campground

name: Sawmill Cg
description: Sawmill Campground has 3 small, tight campsites; each with a fire ring and a picnic table.  Sites to pitch a tent are small and limited by aspen within the campground.  Parking is limited.  Large RVs and  trailers are not recommended.  A single-unit, ADA-accessible SST vault toilet is found at the campground.  Individual campsites are not considered ADA-accessible.  An excellent site for a small picnic near a creek.  Aspen trees shade the campsites.

name: North Fork Siuslaw
description: Dispersed camping area with 7 campsites.

name: SALTER'S CABIN
description: Salters Cabin Horse Camp is located in a shaded, second-growth, ponderosa pine forest and makes for a great escape from those hot summer days!  There is a corral on site for folks camping with horses to use. The cabin on site is for historic purposes and the Forest Service recommends that visitors do not enter or camp in the cabin.

name: Little Lick Horse Camp
description: Little Lick Horse Camp is a primitive equestrian campground with four family camping areas and two double campsites located on a long ridgetop in the southeast corner of Pulaski County. The camp overlooks the Cumberland River and provides access to Little Lick Trail #502 and Nathan McClure Trail #530. Campsites have tent pads, fire rings, lantern posts and picnic tables. Trash collection is not available. Picket lines and corrals are available for horses.

name: PIONEER CG
description: Pioneer Campground, which is situated next to Soldier Mountain Ski Area, is a developed campground composed of 5 units on Soldier Creek. The campground can be reserved in its entirety for groups of up to 50 people. The amphitheater and adjacent picnic area can be used for group events. Campground amenities include picnic tables, fire rings, drinking water and a restroom. The South Fork and North Fork of Soldier Creek trails begin along  Forest Road 093 and join a major network of trails in the Soldier Mountains.

name: Sunshine Bar
description: Lush campsites at Sunshine Bar Campground are located on the Wild and Scenic Elk River, and along the Wild Rivers Coast Scenic Bikeway.Facilities6 campsites with picnic tables, and fire pitsNo drinking water2 vault toiletsNo garbage disposal - Please pack it out;

name: DEEP CREEK HUNT CAMP
description: The Deep Creek Hunt Camp is a three-sided shelter available for free public use.  There is a picnic table and fire ring located onsite.  There is a fourteen day stay limit within a 30 day period at this shelter.

name: SCHIPPER CG
description: Schipper Campground is a developed, fee campground composed of 5 individual units adjacent to Birch Creek. It is an accessible day use area and is a convenient retreat for visitor's from nearby Twin Falls, ID. The campground is suitable for tents and includes limited space for motor homes and trailers. This area is accessible for a season that varies usually between April and October. Campground amenities include accessible toilets, however no water is available.

name: Blue Crossing Cg
description: Located near the riverside at6200 ' elevation within the beautiful Blue River Valley, Blue Crossing Campground is a perfect choice for a peaceful, rustic camping experience in a beautiful setting well off the beaten path. It also provides a convenient base camp for anyone seeking to explore the Blue Range Primitive Area via the Tutt Creek Trailhead.4 total campsites, 2 with Adirondack-style shelters.Trailer 16 ' maxAccess to Blue Range Primitive Area.14 day stay limit.

name: Paragon Dispersed Camping Area
description: Paragon Dispersed Camping Area is a primitive camping area with ten designated campsites, some with lantern posts and fire rings. The area is located off of KY 519 on a narrow portion of Cave Run Lake which provides calm paddling conditions for non-motorized boating. The site design also allows for easy vehicle access all the way to the water's edge. Trash collection is available seasonally.

name: Los Burros #1
description: LOS BURROS #1 (Trailhead)

name: Cottonwood Cg - Ton
description: Closed for Camping.     Day use only.     Potable water available

name: COTTONWOOD
description: This very rustic, primitive camp is located near Rock Creek and the route of the Historic Summit Trail. The small campground offers seven camp sites interspersed with aspen and surrounded by a mixed conifer forest, which provides shade during summer months.

name: Turney Gulch Group Campground
description: Located seven miles southeast of Crown King, Arizona.  This group site is situated close to Horsethief lake. Popular activities include boating, fishing, hiking, and visiting the Castle Creek Wilderness. This group site has fifteen tables and grill with a roofed ramada/pavilion. Facilities Historic wooden pavilion10 tables no services available Drinking water Vault toilet Garbage service High-clearance vehicles are recommended for those who plan to visit recreation sites in Horsethief Basin. Horsethief Basin Brochure (12.8 MB PDF)

name: THOMS CREEK CROSSING
description: The Thoms Creek Crossing Campsite is a fully accessible, single occupancy campsite on the south end of Wrangell Island.  Access is via a short footpath from the parking area at the bridge to the site on the shore of Thom's Creek.

name: ELKHORN
description: Located on the edge of Forest Service land in the Maury Mountains and nestled under large ponderosa pine trees, this campground is relatively easy to reach yet still has a secluded feel. ; It is conveniently located near the Maury Mountain agate beds which host red, green, and gold moss agates. Find out more about rockhounding in Central Oregon at our Rocks and Minerals page.

name: HOGBACK LAKE RUSTIC CAMPGROUND
description: The Hogback Lake Area has a rustic campground with 3 sites, a 5 mile trail system passing 6 lakes with several different loops, and 5 backcountry campsites along the trail.  There is also a boat launch and an accessible fishing pier.  There is no garbage pick up at Hogback Lake Rustic Campground.  Plan to pack out all your garbage, including fish remains from cleaning fish.

name: Forks
description: FORKS (Campground)

name: Penny Springs Campground
description: PENNY SPRINGS CAMPGROUND (Campground)

name: Crooked Creek Dispersed Area
description: This is a dispersed campsite along Crooked Creek that offers camping space for 1 to 4 parties.  It consists of 4 rough level dirt pull-outs where trailers and tents can be set up.

name: WHISTLER
description: Located on the northern edge of Mill Creek Wilderness, this campground is located within walking distance from the Wildcat North Trailhead. There are many standing dead trees here so be careful where you wander and where you set your camp. Whistler Springs rockhounding site is located within the campground shortly downhill from the restroom that has a tendency to draw enthusiasts. ; For visitors who are interested in either hiking in preserved wilderness areas, or scavenging for some beautiful stones this is a great place to spend some time. Visit our Rocks and Minerals page for more information on rockhounding. View a vicinity map of Mill Creek Wilderness and trails; NOTE: The road getting to the campground, as well as the road within the campground, are both very rough. Recreational vehicles and trailers are not recommended.

name: JACKSON CREEK
description: Jackson Creek Campground has 14 campsites with tables, bear proof food lockers, vault toilets and parking. There is no trash service. Jackson Creek Campground is located on the edge of Jackson Creek in a mixed conifer forest. Very remote campground with limited services. Road is very rough, rocky, and narrow.

name: Tajique
description: TAJIQUE (Campground)

name: 566 PINEY CREEK HC
description: The Piney Creek Horse Trail is a system of horse trails that meanders approximately 53 miles through the East Texas pineywoods in the Davy Crockett National Forest.  Trail riding groups of more than 75 persons (including spectators) will need a Special-Use Permit and should contact the District Office three months prior to the ride date. The trail is primitive. Use caution in wet weather since parts of the trail flood.  Some sections of the trail route around the bottomlands and can be used even in wet weather.

name: Fr 9350
description: Dispersed Camping Area. Vault toilet is located at entrance to campground at the Carr Lake Trail Head. This camping area is located immediately adjacent to the Mogollon Rim Escarpment and several campsites are bordered by a 200 ' vertical drop. This area is not recommended for families with young children or people who are uneasy with heights.

name: Bullseye Lake
description: BULLSEYE LAKE (Campground)

name: NELSON GROUP CG
description: Located near Westgard Pass and White Mountain Road, three separate large group sites are popular with academic institutions for geology field trips. Surrounded by Pinyon and Juniper, Camp Nelson, Camp Noren, and Camp Ferguson all have shade ramada ' s, campfire ring, picnic table, and vault toilets. These sites are dry, the nearest water source is Big Pine.

name: Trapper John Shelter
description: ¿Built and maintained by the Dartmouth Outing Club, the Trapper John Shelter is located 1. 1 miles from Dorchester Road via Holts Ledge Trail (Appalachian Trail) and spur trail.  The 3-walled shelter can accommodate 8 people.  The site has a composting privy and a fire ring.  There is a water source nearby.

name: Table Rock Camping Area
description: Table Rock is a small, dispersed campsite with limited development off Rock Creek Road in McCreary County. The campsite is along Rock Creek, a Kentucky Wild River, and nearby Mushroom Rock Day Use site.

name: East Dallas Camping Area
description: East Dallas Camping Area is located on Ouray County Road 7, outside of Ridgway, CO. This area provides dispersed camping recreational opportunities. This area is within close proximity to multiple motorized and non-motorized recreational trails. One toilet is available in this area.

name: No Name Lake
description: No Name Lake is 17.6 acre 30' deep, scenic lake with excellent opportunities for cutthroat trout fishing.  The lake has access for small boats only.  Canoes, kayaks and float tubes have to be portaged down the  short trail from the campground to the lake.  A campground with six campsites and a concrete vault toilet is located on the east side of the lake.  Camping is allowed only at the six designated campsites. *Campground Closed Currently Day use only

name: Hexacuba Shelter
description: ¿Built and maintained by the Dartmouth Outing Club, this 8-person hexagonal shelter is located on a 0. 2 mile spur path off Kodiak Trail (Appalachian Trail) 1. 6 miles south of the south peak of Mt.  Cube.  A privy is provided.  The water source is a small brook at a spur path junction and may be unreliable.

name: Johns Camp Shelter
description: JOHNS CAMP SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: BROWN CREEK
description:
Dispersed Camping Area, No trash service, No restrooms, No water.
This is a Pack It In Pack It Out campground.  Pack out everything you bring with you.

name: OLD EAST FORK
description: Located a short distance west of Yellow Pine, on the old East Fork road between the East Fork South Fork Salmon River and the upgraded East Fork road. There are 10 camp sites with metal fire rings, and 2 vault toilets.

name: PROMONTORY PIT ROAD
description: Dispersed Camping Area

name: Cimarron Forks Camping Area
description: Cimarron Forks Camping Area is located at the confluence of the Middle and East Fork Rivers near Silver Jack Reservoir. This area provides dispersed camping opportunities. The area is also within close proximity to multiple hiking and OHV trails. Two vault toilets area available in this area.

name: Milton Reservoir
description: Dispersed camping only. Vault toilet, but no other services are provided.

name: Pleasant Valley
description: The Pleasant Valley Campground is located approximately 32 miles southwest of Libby on Highway 2. The campground has 7 sites tables and fire rings and able to accommodate up to a 32' rd. There is also 2 stock campsites with feed bins and a corrals. Campground roads and parking spurs are gravel or native material. Amenities include vault toilets.

name: Pearl Pass Dispersed Campground
description: 7 dispersed campsites for car camping along Pearl Pass Road. High Clearance required and 4x4 recommended to access all campsites. All sites are first come first serve. No facilities such as toilets or water are available. Maximum 5 day stay limit.

name: Blue Bend Loop Trail Shelter
description: BLUE BEND LOOP TRAIL SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: CRANE CROSSING
description: This is a small rustic camp area near the North Fork Malheur Wild and Scenic River. This site is a great get away for those looking for something quiet and out of the way. The camping area sets just at the trailhead. The trail can be taken to the west and go along the Crane Creek trail or north and head up to the North Fork Malheur trailhead.

name: PASS CREEK NARROWS CAMPING AREA & PICNIC SITE
description: The area has seven camping sites scattered through scenic Pass Creek Narrows. There is an accessible vault toilet, No drinking water. Nearby areas of interest include Hidden Mouth Cave, and Mud Lake/Blacktail ATV trail.

name: Fr 169
description: Dispersed Camping Area

name: Search Bay Dispersed Camping Area
description: Search no more for your perfect, off-the-beaten-track campsite and swimming hole.  At Search Bay you will be surrounded by:Aspen grovesCedar swampsMeadows and pondsDeerBald eaglesLoonsHow to Get to Search Bay?A single-track dirt road, (Forest Road 3436) starts from Michigan Highway 134 (M-134) and meanders through aspen groves, cedar swamps, meadows and ponds to an unimproved camping area along the edge of Search Bay. Primitive Camping:Camping is primitive, with no facilities such as tables, toilets or drinking water. Wildlife:The diversity of habitats along the road attracts a variety of wildlife, so stop frequently to scan the surrounding area. During the breeding season in spring, watch for nesting bald eagles and listen for loons calling from the water. Walk along the edge of the bay in the spring and fall and scan the adjacent trees and shrubs for migrating songbirds. In the summer, stop for a swim and watch for waterfowl feeding in the shallow bay. This is also an important winter deer range as the browse line on the trees indicates. Small Boats Allowed:Trails traverse the area and provide a wonderful experience.  Depending on water levels, the boat launch may be used to launch small boats.  Kayak and canoe access is available.

name: UPPER BUCK CREEK
description: Upper Buck Creek is your destination for rustic seclusion in a high mountain setting. Located 30 minutes southwest of Silver Lake, Oregon, ponderosa, lodgepole pine trees, aspen, and willows co-exist with open meadows and marsh land. This quiet forest camp is a great place to relax, fish, walk along the creek, and enjoy nature. Upper Buck Creek features five campsites with fire rings, and one vault toilet. There are no garbage receptacles, so remember to "pack it in, pack it out." There is no potable water. Visitors need to pack plenty of water.

name: Klahanie
description: Klahanie is located on the South Fork Calawah River; and has; a; typical; temperate coastal rainforest canopy, including; old growth spruce over 8' in diameter, hanging mosses and a lush carpet of wood sorel and sword fern. Klahanie provides a beautiful, inexpensive "base camp" to explore the unique shops and calendar events of Forks, as well as the; spectacular surrounding landscape sounds. It is 20 minutes from the; rugged Pacific Ocean coast and LaPush cultural center for the Quileute People, 25; minutes from the Bogachiel Rain Forest, and an hour from Cape Flattery bluffs and the Makkah Cultural Center. Caution: Children should always be supervised around water. In recent years the river has eroded its bank.

name: BINGO BROOK
description: General Forest Camping; Recreational Opportunity Guide

name: Elbow Lake
description: This lake is situated 9.5 miles West of Northport. The lake is now in two segments, the North 7.1 acres are a marshy area, and the South is 6.4 acres with a steep path down from the campground. This campground is quiet and off the beaten path. It's a great place to really get away. Sites are more suited to tent camping than trailers or large RVs.

name: LOWER HYALITE
description: A campground in the Hyalite Canyon on Bozeman District. The campground offers group site that can accommodate up to 100 people. It can be used for overnight camping or day-use picnicking.

name: Wilson Lake
description: Wilson Lake Rustic Campground is on the shore of the lake and has a drive down boat ramp with a dock. Nearby Little Wilson Lake also has a boat ramp, and there is a portage trail from Wilson to Sister Lake. Wilson Lake Rustic Campground offers 4 sites accessible by car. On the shore of the lake is an additional backcountry campsite accessible by boat, and there is another backcountry site on Little Wilson.  There is no garbage pick up at Wilson Lake Rustic Campground.  Plan to pack out all your garbage, including fish remains from cleaning fish.

name: Buttercup Campground
description: A small, quiet campground, this site is primarily used by river paddlers. Located in stands of mixed hardwoods and pine, campers may be surprised by a wildlife visitor or two while enjoying close-up views of the river.

name: BILLY FIELDS
description: Billy Fields Campground is a great starting point for those wanting to hunt, fish, or look for wild horses. For those wishing to hike and explore Fields Peak Trail is within 3 miles of the campground. This campground features picnic tables and metal fire rings.

name: OREGON MINE
description: Adjacent to Murderer 's Creek, this little campground is a great base camp for hunters. The campground is a nice area for those wishing to horse camp, a buck and pole corral is located adjacent to the campground. Visitors to the campground can enjoy bird watching, hunting and fishing in near by creeks. Hikers have options in the Cedar Grove Botanical area and Fields Peak trail. Visitors may get the opportunity to see one of the beautiful wild horses that reside in the area.

name: CLEARWATER #2 FORBAY FOREST CAMP
description: Clearwater #2 Forbay Forest Camp offers 5 campsites around the forebay. This camping area covers a quiet, secluded adventure if you enjoy a night under the starts. Nearby recreation attractions include, Toketee Falls, Umpqua Hot Springs, and Watson Falls. There are no garbage services at this campsite, so please be prepared to pack out your trash.

name: Big Springs - Rec Site
description: Designated Dispersed Camping Area. Parking areas are designated and tables and fire rings located at the sites. Vault toilet nearby. No water

name: Bull Mountain Campground
description: Minimally developed campground without individually numbered campsites. No picnic tables or fire rings present. Most campsites lack shade. The access road is closed to motor vehicles between Nov. 15 and June 15.

name: SHIEFER
description: Shiefer Campground is an undeveloped site on the Salmon River with views of the South Fork canyon country all around. Elevation 3050 feet. Trails lead along the river into the Frank Church River of No Return Wilderness. A shorter trail leads to Pilot Peak lookout. Please pack out your trash. This campground takes several hours to reach by car from McCall and is not serviced on a regular basis.

name: Sawkaw Lake Campsites
description: SAWKAW LAKE BACKCOUNTRY CAMPSITES (Camping Area)

name: Porcupine Island Camp
description: PORCUPINE ISLAND CAMP (Campground)

name: LONG LAKE - W38
description: A concrete boat ramp provides access to the 926 acre Long Island Lake. Long Island Lake is just east of MN Highway 84. Northern pike, largemouth bass, and panfish such as bluegills, sunfish and perch are found in this lake.

name: MOOSE MOUNTAIN SHELTER
description: ¿This  '||chr(39)||'Adirondack '||chr(39)||' style shelter sits atop the ridge of Moose Mountain off a;loop trail;from the Moose Mountain Trail (Appalachain Trail).  This shelter was built by the Dartmouth Outing Club;entirely by hand;-using no;power tools.  It replaced the previous existing shelter;located;on the old Clark Pond Loop Trail.  The shelter accomodates;8.  A;privy and 2 tent platforms are on separate side paths off the loop trail.  Marginal water is nearby.

name: Rapid Creek Dispersed
description: This is a small, quiet two-unit dispersed camping area located in the Paddy Flat area. Adjacent to Rapid Creek.

name: Jackson Creek
description: JACKSON CREEK (Campground)

name: Black Flat Cua Dispersed
description: Dispersed Camping Area.

name: TROUT LAKE GOLF COURSE CAMPSITE M33
description: Dispersed campsite with metal grate firepit.

name: BIG BAYHORSE CAMPGROUND
description: A beautiful high mountain lake is the setting for this out of the way campground. Plenty of fishing in lake and streams. Good hiking and ATV trail access. Campsite facilities include picnic tables and fire rings with cooking grills. Within the campground there are vault toilets and a day use picnic area. On Bayhorse Lake campers will find a boat launch and two boat docks for use by non-motorized watercraft. This dirt road is narrow and steep and while trailers are allowed, caution is advised; best fit for trailers and motorhomes less than 32 feet long. No drinking water is on site, and please pack out your trash.

name: Orr Lake
description: Orr Lake is a popular fishing area with a beautiful view of Mt Shasta. The lake is the home of trout, bass, and catfish. A scenic trail along the east edge of the lake provides access to several fishing jetties and connects the 4 campsites on the east side of the lake with the 4 double sites on the north end of the lake. A boat ramp on the east shore and a hand-launch boat ramp on the north end also provide easy access to the lake.

name: Cathedral Pines Campground
description: The access road is gated to prohibit motorized access. Visitors to this campground are primarily river paddlers. To access the site from the road, visitors will need to walk . 25 miles into the large, old-growth eastern white pine to find the campground. Trees offer a screen from the river, but still allow campers views of the river and wildlife.

name: HARVES RIVER CUA DISPERSED
description: Dispersed camping site. Facilities include vault toilet and information kiosk. Fishing opportunity at Farnsworth Reservoir.

name: Ten Mile Overflow And Ten Mile Road
description: Proposed campground

name: Pointy Knob Shelter
description: POINTY KNOB SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: Lower Glady Dispersed Camp Site
description: LOWER GLADY DISPERSED CAMP SITE (Camping Area)

name: Cloud Crossing Rec Area
description: This recreation complex is located along the banks of the beautiful Saline Bayou Wild & Scenic River. Recreation opportunities consist of fishing, camping, boating, hiking, and picnicking. An abundance of wildlife can be observed.

name: Golden Trout Crossing
description: This campground has 15 first come sites. One of the sites is accessible and some sites can accommodate large groups. Campground amenities include water and vault toilets. Campsite amenities include picnic tables and fire ring. Stream fishing, day hiking, nature viewing and  OHV riding are some of the local attractions.

name: TURN ISLAND BEACH
description: Located on the west shore of Wrangell Island, Turn Island Beach Campsite includes two tent platforms for camping and picnicking with a shared outhouse facility.  The site is on saltwater, and can be accessed either by boat or on foot via the Nemo Saltwater Access Trail on Wrangell Island.

name: GALE RIVER LOOP
description: Gale River Loop Dispersed camping includes 13 primitive car-camping campsites.   Camping is allowed at desigted sites only at this  pack-in/pack-out facility .

name: SPLIT CREEK CAMPING
description: Desigted dispersed camping near the Split Creek TH, located at the beginning of the Cow Creek Road NFSR #50387.  There are 4 separate sites with metal fire rings and a CXT vault toilet.  TH access for Split Creek Trail #081 and North Fork Lick Creek Trail #082 is nearby.

name: Whelan Lake Campsites
description: This area is popular for canoeing, fishing and camping. The camping area is near the south branch of the Pere Marquette River, on Whelan Lake.  The land surrounding the lake is primarily federal ownership.

name: FRENCH CABIN SNO-PARK
description: French Cabin offers 12 miles of groomed snowmobile trails. Approximately 25 parking spaces. More information can be found on the Washington State Parks Winter Recreation Website.

name: GREEN CABIN FLAT
description: 1,000-foot elevation. Undeveloped camping area on the wild and scenic Kings River. This area is secluded and requires significant travel time to visit giant sequoia trees. Whitewater rafting down to Pine Flat Reservoir, with up to Class III rapids. Special food storage rule in effect because this is black bear country. Check current fire restrictions before venturing out.

name: Smokey Boulder Dispersed
description: Numerous dispersed camp sites located along Smokey Boulder Road #074. Busiest during hunting season in September and October. Pack it in pack it out. No water. Some sites contain fire rings and tables, most do not.

name: Reed Ranch Airstrip Developed Site
description: Located off the west side of the South Fork Salmon River NFSR #50674, approximately .5 miles w/SW of Camp Creek Campground.  There are three airplane tie-downs and campsites available for aviators, with an additiol 2 metal fire pits and sites available for road-access visitors.  A CXT vault toilet is available as well.

name: Shell Reservoir Camping Area
description: Fishing is allowed year-round, ice usually clears around early June. This fishery is comprised mainly of Brook trout, which are maintained by natural reproduction.

name: Winfield Trailhead
description: xxx

name: BOTTLE BAY CG
description: BOTTLE BAY CG

name: Bear Run Campsites
description: BEAR RUN CAMPSITES (Camping Area)

name: Lower Sandy
description: Dispersed camping area in the Baker Lake area with some amenities.

name: BLACK CANYON
description: Tucked into a tall stand of fir trees along Jackson Creek, this Black Canyon Campground has three sites with picnic tables and fire rings. Take a dip with nearby swimming access. Visitors who stay at this campground can explore nearby popular recreation site, the World's Tallest Sugar Pine Tree. There are no services at this campground. Do your part by following the principles of Leave No Trace and pack out all garbage.

name: Bear Creek Equestrian Camp
description: Developed campground with amenities, picnic tables, fire rings, grills and vault toilet

name: Alamosa Campground
description: Alamosa Campground is on the Alamosa River 4.5 miles above Terrace Reservoir Dam. There are 5 campsites, one is pull through,  with tables and fireplaces, and ample parking. At present, there are no restrooms, vault type toilets will be installed later this summer. There is public fishing at Terrace Reservoir and trail access to Alamosa-Rock Creek and Big Lake Trails. Maneuvering space for large trailers and recreation vehicles is limited. Naturally acidic water severely limits fishing in the Alamosa river between Stunner Campground and Terrace Reservoir.

name: Bay City Campground
description: BAY CITY (Campground) - Dispersed Camping area.

name: GUT LAKE - NCT W53
description: Carry in dispersed campsite on Gut Lake

name: PINE VALLEY
description: Horse Camp, access to Crabtree trailhead. Trail leads to Emigrant Wilderness. Please practice Leave No Trace and Pack it in, Pack it out principles.

name: EAST FORK BAKER CREEK CG
description: East Fork Baker Creek Campground is a primitive non-fee, non-reservation campground composed of 7 campsites located by the East Fork of Baker Creek. This area is accessible from June through November. Campground amenities include a vault toilet and fire rings. Fishing is available in Baker Creek.

name: COLD MEADOWS AIRFIELD
description: Located within the Frank Church River of No Return Wilderness adjacent to the Cold Meadows Administrative Guard Station. This airfield serves as a jump off point for multiple backcountry trails.

name: BIG OAK  HUNTER CAMP
description: Big Oak Hunter Camp is our only physically disabled hunting area in the Talladega National Forest. This camp is a 1700 acre hunting unit for physically disabled hunters possessing the required State permits in Choccolocco Wildlife Management Area. Big Oak Hunter Camp also has sanitary facilities.

name: Upper Deadman Cg
description: Elevation 7800 feet. 20 campsites. Campground is not suitable for RV camping. Tent or car camping only. No drinking water is available. 14 day stay limit. A limited  number of bear lockers are shared at this site.

name: BESSIE SHELTER
description: Facilities Campsites with picnic tables, and fire rings No drinking water No toilet No garbage disposal - Please pack it out;

name: GAME LAKE
description: This dispersed site provides access to Kalmiopsis Wilderness. Located on a small lake with meadows - a geologist '||chr(39)||'s dream! For tents or small campers only.Facilities3 campsites with picnic tables and fire pitsNo drinking waterVault toiletNo garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: San Juan Cua
description: Generally, open May to October as weather and conditions allow. Dispersed Campground in an open setting with views of the canyon. Access to Toiyabe Crest tiol Recreation Trail by the San Juan Trailhead. County Road 21 intersects, and in places follows, the Austin-Grantville Stage Route (1861-1866)

name: Oscar Miller
description: OSCAR MILLER (Camping Area)

name: Hitt Mountain Dispersed Campground And T/H
description: HITT MOUNTAIN DISPERSED CAMPGROUND AND T/H (Camping Area)

name: Double Falls Cg
description: Double Falls Campground

name: Echo Beach Campground
description: Small campground with a short downhill walk to access the Illinois River.  Facilities:  2 sites with picnic tables and fire rings, no drinking water, no trash service - Please pack it out.

name: Clark Mountain Camp
description: CLARK MOUNTAIN CAMP (Campground)

name: Fourth Of July Camp
description: Home to yet another one of our glorious wooden suspension pack bridges, at the junction of FS Road 250 and the Fourth of July pack bridge, the Fourth of July Trailhead offers a few dispersed campsites and many breathtaking views.  Visitors traveling the Windy Ridge Trail will experience beautiful scenery and views into the 1910 Great Burn areas and the Lolo Motorway. The Idaho Centennial Trail also shares a portion of the trail between trails 531 and 634.

name: Government Landing Access
description: This camping area is named for Government Island.  The 3 campsites are part of the Forest Services ' 41 designated dispersed sites along the Upper Manistee River.  The main access road along the powerline is a snowmobile trail in the winter. Brochure with map: Manistee River This brochure is set to print on 11 x 17 paper, landscape (wide) orientation.  To print on 8 1/2 x 11 paper set the print area to  'shrink to printable area ', this will make the text on the page smaller. Flickr Photo Albums Manistee River

name: Lost Valley Dispersed Sites
description: LOST VALLEY DISPERSED SITES (Camping Area)

name: VELVET ROCKS SHELTER
description: ¿The Velvet Rocks Shelter is located on the Velvet Rocks Trail 1. 2 miles from the official western terminus of the trail near NH Rte 120 and Chase Field House in Hanover.  A privy is located nearby.  Water is accessed along the loop trail but may be unreliable in dry months.

name: Azalea Cove
description: This is a walk-in, bike-in or boat-in campground.

name: Wildell Shelter
description: WILDELL SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: North Bend Campsites
description: NORTH BEND CAMPSITES (Camping Area)

name: Turkey Run Primitive Camp
description: TURKEY RUN TRAILHEAD  FNST Camp Shelter with Kiosk

name: IRON PHONE JUNCTION
description: This area has four campsites with fire rings, hitching rails, and no feed bunks provided.

name: RESERVOIR C
description: Close to the boat ramp and right on the water, campsites at Reservoir C are quiet, scenic and partly shady.A recommended spot for Amateur Astronomers. Light polution is non-existant.

name: CRAWFISH LAKE SHELTER
description:
A short, fairly flat grade trail travels through the forest to the small, tranquil Crawfish Lake and a trail shelter. The lake is shallow and less than three acres in size. The trail continues around the lake. The portion of trail to the lake and the shelter is accessible with moderate difficulty. However, access to the water's edge and around the lake is not accessible. Activities include picnicking, photography, primitive camping at a three-sided shelter, and limited fishing. This area is an excellent habitat for raptors and salamanders.
The easy ten-minute hike to the lake replaces the original steep, rocky trail that descended from Adams Mountain Road above. Help protect the natural beauty of this area. Please pack out all your garbage and leave the area better than you find it.

name: Summit Lake
description: This fee free campground has one vault toilet and no picnic tables or fire rings. It is not suitable for trailers due to road conditions.

name: GULL POINT CAMPSITE
description: GULL POINT CAMPSITE

name: Twin Springs Campground
description: Located 40 minutes southeast of Lakeview, Oregon, Twin Springs Campground offers three peaceful campsites at 6,300 feet elevation. Twin Springs is piped out of the rocky hillside near the center of the forest camp amid tall ponderosa pine, white fir, and aspen trees. There is a lush riparian understory along the creek and bright wildflowers in the late spring and summer. Amenities at Twin Springs include picnic tables, fire grates, and one vault toilet. Visitors can enjoy bird watching, wildlife viewing (deer are common) and hiking on the Crane Mountain National Recreation Trail #161, located two miles west and accessed near Rogger Meadow. Visitors need to pack plenty of water as there is no potable water onsite.

name: Meadow Springs Campground
description: Located on the edge of a red pine plantation, visitors to this site may see many varieties of wildlife in addition to their view of the Au Sable River. This camping area is a short .25 mile walk from the gate, but is primarily used by river paddlers. There is no motorized access to this site. Brochure with map: This brochure is set to print on 11 x 17 paper, landscape (wide) orientation. To print on 8 1/2 x 11 paper set the print area to  "shrink to printable area", this will make the text on the page smaller.

name: CAMINO COVE CG
description: Elevation 4,875'. 32 units. Vault toilets, fire rings. No water, grills or tables. No Fee. Check ahead - campfires may not be allowed during fire restrictions.

name: Mikes Run Shelter
description: MIKES RUN SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: KIWANIS
description: This is a one-unit dispersed camping area along Mann Creek. It is next to the road so it can be noisy and dusty. There is no potable water available at the site, so come prepared with your own. Typical season of use is mid-May through late September or early October.

name: FR 237
description: Dispersed Camping Area. Vault Toilet located at Willow Springs Loop Trailhead along FR 237.

name: ROCKY RIDGE CAMPGROUND
description: This is a small, 3 site campground with a tight turning radius. Individual sites are not large enough to accommodate camper trailers or RV's.

name: West Virginia Creek
description: Rustic campsites with fire rings in Jeffrey Pine Forest. There is no water and no trash service. Please pack out your trash

name: Goose Lake Dispersed
description: GOOSE LAKE DISPERSED (Camping Area)

name: SKILLET CREEK
description: Skillet Creek Campground has two campsites along the upper South Umpqua River. This rustic campground has easy river access for swimming and is close to the South Umpqua Falls Day Use Area. There are no garbage services at this campground so please be prepared to pack out your trash.

name: ELK LAKE DISPERSED SITE
description: Two dispersed camping areas located on beautiful Elk Lake area. One campsite is at the south end of Elk Lake and another is located at The Narrows of Elk Lake. A vault toilet is located at each location.

name: Partridge Creek Camp
description: Northeast of the Elk Creek Reservoir, located in Elk River, Idaho, the Partridge Creek Campground offers 13 primitive campsites, access to the 3.5 mile Patridge Creek ATV Trail, and an opportunity to drive our scenic Elk River Backcountry Byway!

name: KERRICK CORRALS
description: Kerrick Horse Campground Camp in designated sites only. The number of people allowed in a single campsite is six. The maximum length of stay in any campground is 14 days. Please leave the area in as good (or better) condition than you found it. Please practice Leave No Trace and Pack it in, Pack it out principles.

name: Alpine Plateau Camping Area
description: Undeveloped area popular for dispersed camping.

name: Bromley Shelter
description: overnight shelter located on the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and coincident Long Trail

name: Boulder Meadows
description: BOULDER MEADOWS (Horse Camp)

name: CURRIER SPRING
description: Located one hour west of Paisley, Oregon, Currier Springs horse camp lies in an open meadow. Currier Springs features four camping sites with campfire rings, and picnic tables. It also boasts a newer corral with four stalls, built by the Back Country Horsemen, that can accommodate four to eight horses. Horses can be watered, using the historical trough constructed by the Civilian Conservation Corps. From Currier Springs you can access the Fremont National Recreation Trail for miles of backcountry riding. You'll view spectacular mountain scenery as you ride along the top of a 2,000 feet high fault block rim, known as Winter Rim or Winter Ridge. As the trail heads west to Hager Mountain, there are vistas of Summer Lake. It's about a 29 mile ride to Antler Horse Camp. There is no portable water. Visitors need to pack plenty of water.

name: EAGLE MEADOWS
description: Campground is designed for equestrian use and for those who are camping with horses and mules.  Please refrain from operating OHVs in campground.  Horses and mules are easily spooked by ATVs and motorcycles, therefore it is recommended no OHV camping in the campground. Camp in designated sites only. The number of people allowed in a single campsite is six. The maximum length of stay in any campground is 14 days. Please leave the area in as good (or better) condition than you found it. Please practice Leave No Trace and Pack it in, Pack it out principles.

name: Isabella Landing Camp
description: ISABELLA LANDING CAMP (Campground)

name: JONES CREEK CAMPGROUND
description: Basic Camping No Utilities, Boat Ramp

name: Tule Bay
description: TULE BAY (Campground)

name: MORRELL CUA DISPERSED
description: Dispersed Camping Area

name: Clear Spring
description: Clear Springs is located southwest of Paisley, Oregon and can be reached in approximately one hour. At an elevation of about 5400 feet, this campground is situated right along Dairy Creek. There is one picnic table, fire ring, and one vault toilet, including a variety of dispersed camping spaces. This camp is primarily used by hunters during hunting season. You can fish for rainbow trout in Dairy Creek. There is potable water, but no garbage service. Remember to "pack it in, pack it out.

name: Earl Tennant Campground
description: EARL TENNANT CAMPGROUND (Campground)

name: Government Island
description: Government Island is the only public land within the Les Cheneaux chain of islands. it was once home to a Coast Guard construction support site. The Forest Service provides established campsites, most include a fire ring and picnic table. There are two public vault toilets on the Island. Permits and fees are not required for individual family use, however, if you have a group or provide tours requiring a fee, it is required that you contact the Hiawatha National Forest, St. Ignace Ranger District to obtain a free or low-cost permit. Government Island is accessible only by private watercraft, the nearest public launch is in Cederville. No mooring is provided. Watercraft can be beached at several locations on the Island or anchored in the channel.

name: Lake Creek Dispersed
description: LAKE CREEK DISPERSED (Camping Area)

name: MOSS MEADOW
description: Located 40 minutes south of Paisley, Oregon, this rustic horse camp affords pretty views of Steens Mountain and Mount Shasta. There is one vaulted toilet and four campsites, each with a picnic table and fire grate, and one hitching post. This is a good choice for a stop-over, as Moss Meadows has four corrals but no options for short trail rides. It's about 20 miles from Moss Meadows to Currier Springs on the Fremont National Recreation Trail. Another option is to ride west from Moss Meadow along the road for about five miles to the Chewaucan River. You need to get permission to ride along the river, as it passes through private land. There are signs posted with contact info or you can obtain phone numbers from the Paisley Ranger District. There is no; portable water. Visitors need to pack plenty of water

name: Horse Camp (Palouse)
description: HORSE CAMP (PALOUSE) (Campground)

name: White Rock
description: White Rock is a primitive campground on Tahoe National Forest managed by PG&E.

name: LARSON RIDGE CG
description: Dispersed Camping Area.

name: Davis Shelter
description: DAVIS SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: NOREN GROUP CG
description: Located near Westgard Pass and White Mountain Road, three separate large group sites are popular with academic institutions for geology field trips. Surrounded by Pinyon and Juniper, Camp Nelson, Camp Noren, and Camp Ferguson all have shade ramada ' s, campfire ring, picnic table, and vault toilets. These sites are dry, the nearest water source is Big Pine.

name: Little Molas Dispersed Campground
description: LITTLE MOLAS DISPERSED CAMPGROUND (Campground) and (Trailhead)

name: Lazy C Trailhead
description: This 1.55-mile trail is for hiking, mountain biking and horseback riding. There is a trailhead facility along Highway 19.This trail connects to the McCormack Lake Ozark Trail spur, which will connect you to the Eleven Point section of the Ozark Trail. Half the distance of the trail follows a gravel two-track, before it narrows to a wide, single-track trail before connecting to the spur Trailhead. A large parking area with several designated sites. It's an open grassy area bounded by a wooden fence with multiple shade trees. A gravel loop road circles through the camping/parking area. The trailhead has hitching posts, information board, corrals, and parking for horse users as well as the general public.

name: FALCON CREEK
description: Falcon Creek Campground is a single-site campground tucked into a quiet stand of old growth fir trees above Falcon Creek, a tributary of upper Jackson Creek. There are no garbage services at this campground so please be prepared to pack out your trash.

name: Muchwater Flat Campground
description: MUCHWATER FLAT CAMPGROUND (Campground)

name: Fr 195
description: Dispersed Camping Area

name: Hansen Mill Campground
description: Elevation: 10,800' This is a small, isolated dispersed campground. Campers will find this to be a good vantage point for viewing vistas of distant mountains. There are 3 camping units at this site with picnic tables and fire rings.  Horse friendly camping. There are no refuse receptacles.  Trails and 4x4 roads are nearby, as well as fishing in East Bellows Creek.  The 4x4 road takes off here for the Wheeler Geological Area attraction.  East Bellows trail #790 goes into the Wilderness Area from here to Wheeler Geologic Area and is a foot or horse trail only, no motorized vehicles or mountain bikes allowed.  Call 719-658-2556 for  "real time " conditions.  14 DAY CAMPING LIMIT.

name: Stunner Campground
description: Stunner campground sits at 9700-foot in elevation beside the Alamosa River, two miles below the top of Stunner Pass. There are 5 campsites with tables, fire pits, and adequate parking. Firewood is limited. Convenient trailer spaces available. The Alamosa River is nearby for fishing. Unfortunately, naturally acidic water severely limits fishing in the Alamosa River between Stunner Campground and Terrace Reservoir. Big game hunting is possible.The ghost town of Stunner is just east of the campground. This was a mining town that failed, due to nonproducing mines and transportation problems. Parts of the town are private property, so pack out all your trash and observe posted no-trespassing signs.

name: Chamberlain Basin
description: Located in the Frank Church River of No Return Wilderness and adjacent to the Chamberlain Basin Administrative Guard Station.  There are multiple camp sites along the west end, east end and various locations along the southern boundary of the East/West airstrip. Pit toilets and metal fire rings are available.

name: Shingobee - Nct W50
description: Nestled along the rolling hills of the Shingobee River Valley, the Shingobee Recreation Area provides a variety of summer and winter activities. The area offers 6 miles of trails for hiking, hunting, birdwatching, and cross-country skiing in the heart of Minnesota's Northwoods. A sliding hill and a weekend warming chalet are also available for winter fun.

name: LONE ROCK CG
description: walk/bike/boat in

name: Paddy Flat Dispersed
description: This is a small, two-unit dispersed camping site that is great if you have stock or want some peace and quiet.

name: Lost Spring Campground
description: LOST SPRING CAMPGROUND (Campground)

name: Priest Lake Camping Area
description: Priest Lake Camping Area is a popular spot with nine designated camping sites surrounded by stunning mountain views and dense mixed conifer forest. This site is a first come, first served camping area with NO fee. There are picnic tables and fire rings at each site. There is a vault restroom but no water and no trash service; please PACK IN, PACK OUT. Limited fishing is available at Priest Lake, while the nearby Galloping Goose Trail offers hiking, horseback riding, and mountain biking opportunities. Trailers are not allowed due to a lack of parking availability.

name: Corney Lake Rec Area
description: visitors to the south shore camping area can utilize the facilities which include paved roads, lantern posts, fire rings, restrooms, ample parking, and trash receptacles. Visitors to this area can also use single and group picnic facilities which include a covered group-use shelter, several single picnic tables, a park-like setting with grass, a fishing pier, restrooms, ample parking, and trash receptacles.

name: Marzinski Horse Campground
description:
The Marzinski Trail Campground is open April 1 to December 1, annually. Reservations are required and can be made on Recreation.gov.
The Marzinski Horse Trail and Campground were developed for the horse enthusiasts, who enjoy riding through a forested quiet trail system. The Marzinski Horse Camp serves as the primary access location for the 18 miles of horse trail. The terrain is mostly flat through mixed hardwood and pine forest, marked with blue diamond-shaped markers on trees and cedar signs.
The campground is located in a pine forest.

name: Meadow Creek Cg
description: MEADOW CREEK CG (Camping Area)

name: BINGHAM SPRING
description: This tiny and rustic campground is located adjacent to a meadow and a small pond in the northwestern portion of the Ochoco National Forest.  Mill Creek Wilderness is accessible from this site at Twin Pillars North Trailhead.

name: Railroad Grade Shelter
description: RAILROAD GRADE SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: Isabella Point Camp
description: ISABELLA POINT CAMP (Campground)

name: Reynolds Creek Group Site
description: Located near Priest Lake, this group site has a large covered gazebo, three restroom facilities, fire rings, and bear-resistant storage boxes. Reynolds Creek Group Site is located within walking distance of Priest Lake and the Kalispell Bay Boat Ramp and can host several RVs in an area removed from other campers. Site capacity is 70 people.

name: Condon Lake Backcountry Campsites
description: This area is very popular for mushroom and berry picking, as well as hunting, fishing and camping.

name: Porcupine Rim Campground
description: What was once a dispersed camping area has now become a popular developed campground with a number of amenities. It's situated along the Whole Enchilada mountain bike trail. The camping area provides breathtaking views of Castle Valley below.

name: Bowman Lake Backcountry Campsites
description: The campground is walk-in only, with carry-in canoe access.  This quiet and secluded campground is very popular with fisherman and hunters.

name: Needle Creek Reservoir Camping Area
description: Elevation: 8830'  Needle Creek Reservoir lies between Highways 50 and 114 in the Cochetopa Hills along the headwaters of Needle Creek. This reservoir was constructed in 1962 for irrigation water storage. Its low elevation, 8,830 feet, and easy access make it a favorite fishing area for many. Fishing is usually good at this site, where rainbow and brook trout average ten to eleven inches. Boats are allowed in the reservoir, but most people fish from shore with good success.

name: Upper Manistee River Backcounty Campsites
description: UPPER MANISTEE RIVER BACKCOUNTY CAMPSITES (Camping Area)

name: PRESERVATION POINT CAMPSITE
description: Grand Island is a Congressionally designated National Recreation Area with fascinating history, beautiful overlooks, pristine sandy beaches, dense hardwood forest, serene inland lakes, and miles of hiking and biking trails. This is a unique destination to spend a day or more biking, hiking, exploring, or just hanging out and recharging. Visitors get to the island by passenger ferry from Munising or private watercraft. The dock at Williams Landing can be used for loading and unloading, but boats may not be left there. Jet skis/motorboats are prohibited from landing on shore. Murray Bay, Trout Bay and North Beach have sand beaches with little to no obstructions where a kayak or paddle boat can land. Most locations on the northwest and northeast sides are sheer cliffs. There are 21 designated campsites, including 2 group sites. Reservations are required Memorial Day through Columbus Day, except for Cobble Cove, Flat Rock, and Muskrat Point, which are first-come/first-served. All reservations must be made through Recreation.gov and can be made up to, and including, the day of arrival. Preservation Point: This campsite is located on the north western tip of Grand Island, approximately 1 mile west of North Beach. The site is approximately 9 miles from William's Landing (ferry service arrival point, and visitor information center). The nearest potable water is approximately 6 miles south of this campsite at Juniper Flats Group Campsite. Plan ahead, and bring drinking water when staying at this site. Water can be filtered from Lake Superior which is accessed at North Beach, approximately 1 mile east of this campsite. This site can accommodate up to 6 people in two tents. A primitive latrine, food storage pole, fire ring, and benches are provided in/near the campsite. Preservation Point can be accessed via the island's trail system. This campsite is not directly accessible by kayakers with north Beach being one mile away.

name: HEAD O' BOULDER FOREST CAMP
description: This rustic camp offers a few sites and is also a trailhead which accesses the Vinegar Hill-Indian Rock Scenic Area. From the trailhead visitors can access other trails such as the Princess trail #251, Sunrise Butte Trail #255 and Blackeye Trail #243. Allowing for multiple opportunities for hiking.

name: Horse Canyon Camping Area
description: Stretching from Huntington Canyon westward and ascending toward Scad Valley, Horse Canyon provides a premier nonmotorized trail opportunity. This small camping area at the bottom of the trail provides a place to camp and rest while enjoying the trail.

name: Lincoln Creek Dispersed Campground
description: There are 22 dispersed campsites for car camping along Lincoln Creek Road. High Clearance required and 4x4 recommended to access all campsites. All sites are first come first serve. No facilities such as toilets or water are available. Maximum 5 day stay limit.

name: Cottonwood Pit
description: As you may have guessed, this campground is located in an old gravel pit. When the excavation hit the water table and the pit was filled in with water the operations ceased and the site was abandoned.  Now this campground is locally known as a swimming hole, and is also occasionally stocked with trout.

name: TROUT LAKE BEACH CAMPSITE M34
description: Dispersed campsite with metal grate firepit.

name: Sugar Springs
description: Two campsites on the North side of Thomes Creek, equipped with fire rings and picnic tables.

name: FR 84
description: Dispersed Camping Area

name: Indian Valley Camp
description: This minimally developed campsite has vault toilets but no other features.

name: Oak Flat Campground/Gravel Bar
description: This site is located along the Wild and Scenic Illinois River; and the Illinois River West Trailhead. For tents and small trailers only.Facilities15 campsites with picnic tables and fire pitsNo campground hostNo drinking waterVault toiletNo garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: EAST LOWER VIRGINIA CREEK
description: Rustic campsites with fire rings in Jeffrey Pine Forest. There is no trash service please pack out your trash.

name: Little Rock Campground
description: Littlerock Campground is a primitive campsite nestled in a shaded spruce stand located in beautiful Huntington Canyon along the Huntington Canyon National Scenic Byway. It sits at an elevation of approximately 8,000 feet. Many recreational activities are available, including hiking, biking and fishing. This campsite provides a graveled parking spur, picnic table, and fire ring. There is no water or vault toilet on site but water and a flush restroom can be accessed ¿¿ south of Little Rock Campground at Old Folks Flat Campground.

name: Sulak Campground
description: This site is primarily used by anglers, hunters and families for camping.  There is a short, .25 mile walk from the campsites to the river, through federal and state land.  The river access is operated by the Michigan DNR.

name: Little Bayhorse Camping Area
description: LITTLE BAYHORSE CAMPING AREA (Camping Area)

name: Granite Lake Dispersed
description: GRANITE LAKE DISPERSED (Camping Area)

name: Soldier Bar Airfield
description: Located within the Frank Church River of No Return Wilderness in lower Big Creek draige. This airfield is on the south side of Big Creek and has no trail access other than a short trail down to Big Creek proper.

name: RIVER DUNE BACKCOUNTY GROUP CAMPSITE
description: Located between the Au Sable River Scenic Overlook and Au Sable Loop Campground, this small site is a short . 5 mile walk from the gate. Set back from the road and camping area, campers can enjoy views of the river. Visitors can access the river from a short set of stairs located near the site.

name: Bear Island Backcountry Campsites
description: A small, quiet campground, this site is primarily used by river paddlers. Located in stands of mixed hardwoods and pine, campers may be surprised by a wildlife visitor or two while enjoying close-up views of the river.

name: LAKE OF THE WOODS
description: Lake of the Woods is a small lake that is popular on weekends.  There are approximately 15 camping spots with fire pits and picnic tables situated along the shoreline.  There is no piped water available. This lake generally opens later in the spring as it sits at a high elevation and takes longer for winter snows to melt to gain access.  Camping is free and on a first come - first served basis. The lake has both public and private property.  Fire restrictions may be different depending on whether you are on the public Forest Service campground or the private property.

name: GRAVEL FLAT
description: The campground is located along the north side of the Kings River on a large sandy flat area. There is no shade so it is very hot during the summer months, but is a great place for camping in the spring and fall. Access is paved and dirt (last 1 mile). Vehicles must stay on roads.
