Each site has a table and grill. Please pack out all garbage.Poison Oak abounds in this area, please avoid plants with three leaf clusters: "Leaves of three, let it be!" Watch for rattlesnakes. When fire restrictions are in place (usually during the summer months) NO campfires or charcoal fires are permitted. Camp stoves are permitted. There is no cell phone coverage in the area, but a pay phone is available at Balch Camp.

name: Ferguson Group Camp
description: Located near Westgard Pass and White Mountain Road, three separate large group sites are popular with academic institutions for geology field trips. Surrounded by Pinyon and Juniper, Camp Nelson, Camp Noren, and Camp Ferguson all have shade ramada ' s, campfire ring, picnic table, and vault toilets. These sites are dry, the nearest water source is Big Pine.

name: DIAMOND LAKE - W71
description: Carry in dispersed campsite on diamond Lake

name: Josephine Creek Camp
description: A rustic setting above Josephine Creek and the Illinois River. ; Facilities: 6 campsites with picnic tables and fire pits, no drinking water, vault toilet, no trash service - Please pack it out.

name: ORE HILL TENTSITE
description: This tent site offers  two primitive tent pads.  Water is available 250 ft.  south of the shelter site on a side trail.  Privy is also provided.

name: Deadman Bar Camping
description:
Deadman Bar is small camping area offering three walk-in campsites. The sites are along the East Fork of the Salmon River. Small sandy beaches edge the bar. A vault toilet is adjacent to the parking area.
The grave for an unknown individual is fenced and lies at the eastern end of the campground. The parking lot for the camping area is also the trailhead for Deadman Creek (#075).

name: Spring Hill
description: Spring Hill primarily consists of two distinct areas, not far from each other, that provide excellent dispersed camping opportunities, near water and nestled in Aspen stands. Camping areas are easily accessible off the main Twelve Mile Canyon Road; one on the north side of the road next to the ponds, and the other on the south side of the road. Although they are undeveloped dispersed sites, there are vault toilet facilities on-site.

name: FR 171
description: Dispersed Camping Area

name: CABIN CREEK AIRFIELD
description: Located within the Frank Church River of No Return Wilderness and north of the Big Creek Trail NFST #196. This location is also where the Cabin Creek Administrative Guard Station is located. Multiple camp sites are available near the airfield.

name: River Road Horse Trail Camp
description: The campground for the Shore-to-Shore Trail is adjacent to River Road.  There are picnic tables scattered throughout the site.

name: ELBOW POND
description: The Elbow Pond Day Use area provides a rustic setting for picnicking and canoeing.

name: Lake Sherwood Volunteer Village
description: LAKE SHERWOOD VOLUNTEER VILLAGE (Campground)

name: Dogwood Camp
description: Primitive campground located on Hwy 117 near FH 59 (Longleaf Scenic Byway). The campground has restrooms, water, trash receptacles, and area for trailers/campers.

name: FREIGHTER VIEW CAMPSITE
description: FREIGHTER VIEW CAMPSITE

name: Alta Lakes Camping Area
description: Alta Lakes is a popular dispersed camping area that offers fishing and camping in a spectacular alpine setting. There are 20 designated campsites that are completely undeveloped. The access road to the area is narrow and rough, requiring a high clearance vehicle. Trailers and RV's are not reccomended.

name: RAINEY CREEK
description: Located 10 miles away from Lake Wenatchee, this small campground provides access to Rainy Creek.

name: BEAR WALLOW
description: Located along north side of the Kings River on a large sandy flat area. Take a day hike on the Bear Wallow trail located just west of the campground. Great place for camping in spring and fall. Very hot during summer months. Please pack out all garbage. No cell phone coverage in the area. Pay phone is available at Balch Camp.

name: Trace Branch Camping Area
description: Trace Branch is a small, dispersed campsite with limited development off Rock Creek Road in McCreary County. The campsite is along Rock Creek, a Kentucky Wild River.

name: NORTH LAVA FLOW
description: Campground open year-round pending snow accessibility. No fee campground maintained by FS.

name: Cannon Beach Campground
description: There are three tent platforms along the beach bluff to the North West of the Cannon Beach Day use area. These sites consists of a tent platform that can be covered with a tarp, a picnic table and a fire ring. This site is used by people beachcombing, walking, picnicking, surfing, and camping.

name: Ship Creek Cg
description: SHIP CREEK CG (Camping Area)

name: Avalanche Campground
description: Avalanche Campground has 6 first-come first-serve campsites. It is located adjacent to Avalanche Creek. Fishing is available in Avalanche Creek and in the Crystal River, which is 3 miles downstream. One of the major trailheads into the Maroon Bells-Snowmass Wilderness is located adjacent to the campground. Proper food storage is required because of potential bear activity.

name: Upper Payette Lake Dispersed
description: There are several dispersed campsites along the lakeshore located around Upper Payette Lake.

name: Columbine Campground
description: Columbine Campground offers diverse camping opportunities in two units on the Uncompahgre Plateau. The unit on the west side of the Divide Road has several small campsites that are best for small groups and tents. The larger section on the east side of Divide Road has numerous campsites that can accomodate large RVs. Each campsite has a fire ring/grill, and some have tables. Popular activities in the area are hiking, ATV riding, horseback riding, mountain bike riding. The road is unpaved but accessible by 2WD vehicles.

name: Hard Creek Dispersed
description: HARD CREEK DISPERSED (Camping Area)

name: Lower Little Bear Campground
description: Lower Little Bear Campground is a primitive campground nestled in a partially shaded area alongside Huntington Creek. This campground is located in beautiful Huntington Canyon along the Huntington Canyon National Scenic Byway on Utah Highway 31. It sits at an elevation of approximately 7,100 feet. Many recreational activities are available, including hiking, biking and fishing. This campground provides a double site, group site (accommodate 40 people), graveled parking spur, picnic table, and fire ring. There is no water or a vault toilet on site but a restroom can be accessed ¿¿ north of Lower Little Bear Campground at Little Bear Campground.

name: WABANA-BLUEWATER DISPERSED CAMPSITE M40
description: Dispersed campsite on Wabana Lake with metal grate fire pit.

name: Soap Creek Corral Horse Camp
description: Dispersed camping is available at the horse corrals located adjacent to the Soap Creek Campground. This campground provides access to the southern trails of the West Elk Wilderness.

name: ROUND LAKE CUA DISPERSED
description: Small pond for fishing, a vault restroom available and some dispersed camping in the area.

name: GOVERNMENT MEADOWS HORSE CAMP
description: GOVERNMENT MEADOWS HORSE CAMP

name: TEACHER BAY
description: TEACHER BAY

name: ROADS END CAMPSITE
description: ROADS END CAMPSITE

name: Can Springs Campground
description: Located an hour northeast of Lakeview, Oregon, within the  Warner Mountains, Can Springs births a bubbling creek that flows through this primitive forest camp with a riparian vegetation area bordering it. Large ponderosa pine trees help create a wonderful place to explore or relax in nature's solitude. There are three campsites with picnic tables and fire rings. There is no potable water onsite. Visitors need to pack plenty of water.

name: TIN CUP CAMPGROUND
description: Thirteen campsites on Loon Creek, at the border of the Frank Church River of No Return Wilderness. Each campsite has picnic table and fire ring. There is a vault toilet in the campground. The trail from campground heads into the wilderness. Stock loading facilities available for equestrians outside of the campground.  Horses are not allowed in the campground. Additional trailheads at Indian Springs, Rat Creek, China Creek, Mayfield Creek, and Monte Cristo. Loop hikes to Indian Springs and Rat Creek. Hiking, horse riding, picnicking, and wildlife watching in this area.

name: OLD PINES - NCT W47
description: Carry in dispersed camping site

name: Upper Hell Hole Cg
description: This is a hike-in or boat-in campground at the southeast end of Hell Hole Reservoir.

name: Karr Canyon Upper
description: KARR CANYON UPPER (Campground)

name: LOWER RUSH CREEK
description: Shady campsites and a creek running along side makeLower Rush Creek Campgrounda great getaway destination. Trailers larger than 22 feet are not recommended.In the winter months roads may become sofeet or impassable. Please do not create resource damage by driving on sofeet roads or saturated soil. Remember theweather can change quickly and you do not want to be unpreparedfor extreme conditions.

name: Quemado Lake - El Caso Cg #3
description: QUEMADO LAKE - EL CASO CG #3 (Campground)

name: Blue Valley Camp
description: BLUE VALLEY CAMP (Campground)

name: Lindbergh Lake Campground
description: Lindbergh Lake Campground has 25 designated campsites. Restrooms, fire rings, and food storage boxes are available. Drinking water is not provided; please bring your own source of water. Fishing, swimming, and boating may be enjoyed on the lake. The maximum recommended trailer length for this area is 20 feet. Please pack out what you pack in-- no trash service is provided. There is a trail from the campground which leads part of the way around the west side of the lake.

name: Tumbling Rock Shelter
description: TUMBLING ROCK SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: Powerplant Campground
description: The Power Plant Campground is near Atlanta, Idaho. A trailhead offers access to the Sawtooth Wilderness, heading northeast into a lake-filled basin. The historic mining town of Atlanta is just south of the campground. Good fishing in the river for rainbow trout and whitefish.

name: Franconia Brook Campsites
description: Franconia Brook Tent site is located on the Eastside trail, on the East side of the Pemigewasset River, 3 miles in from the Lincoln Woods trailhead. There are approximately 20 tent sites available for overnight use. The tent sites are first come, first served, include a fire ring and are designated by a numbered stake. There are two pit toilets and water is available at the nearby East Branch. A bear box is available. When possible, please use the bear box instead of hanging food.  Please note: the bear box does become full quickly, so plan accordingly and bring rope as a precaution. Remove all food and trash when leaving.

name: Clear Creek Cg
description: Clear Creek Campground is a non-fee campground and picnic area composed of 12 individual units and reservations are not required. This area is accessible for a season that varies usually between June through October. Campground amenities include toilets and the campground is well suited for tent and RV camping. Sites are handicapped accessible. Bull Flat (#001) and Lake Fork (#004) trails are popular with horseback riders, and hikers.

name: Indian Henry
description: CLOSED DUE TO RIVERSIDE FIRE Indian Henry Campground is located in the Mount Hood National Forest, along the scenic Clackamas River. The campground is a great location for relaxation, providing access to the river and the surrounding wilderness, as well as other scenic spots in the area.

name: Twin Lakes Rec Area
description:
Twin Lakes was once the site of factory buildings, stores and row houses owned by the McKean Chemical Company which made wood alcohol. A company splash dam, used to augment water levels for the chemical plant downstream once occupied the site of today's dam. When McKean Chemical Company closed in the 1920s, the US Forest Service acquired the property.
In 1936, the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) constructed the present dam on Hoffman Run, creating the swimming impoundment. They built the lower campground, picnic area, pavilion and bathhouse. The ""twin"" impoundment was never built, as money planned for its construction was diverted to build Loleta Recreation Area near Marienville, PA.
Twin Lakes has upper and lower camping loops.
The day use area is situated around a 10-acre impoundment which is fed by Hoffman Run, a heavily stocked trout stream; no boating is permitted on the impounded lake. A hardened walking path surrounds the impoundment.

name: LINE CREEK STOCK CAMP
description: Line Creek Stock Camp features 9 pull through units for stock trailers, feed bunks and hitch posts, trailhead parking, and vault toilets. There is no developed water. Attractions include fishing in wild trout waters, beginning of the wild portion of St. Joe Wild and Scenic River, and St. Joe River Trailhead.

name: VAN CREEK
description: VAN CREEK

name: Dry River Shelter # 3
description: DRY RIVER SHELTER # 3 (Campground)

name: Forks Shelter
description: FORKS SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: Elko Cg
description: 3 sites near the Teton River. Fishing for brook trout in the river. Nearby winter sports area at Teton Pass offers downhill skiing and snowmobiling. When there's no snow to play in, hike up Jones Creek, about 3 miles north from campground. The Jones Creek trailhead is about 0.5 mile east of the campground. Bears may frequent the area; keep all food out of sight in approved containers and remove all food from area after eating. Mandatory food storage is required.

name: Lake Alice Campground
description: Lake Alice Campground has 9 campsites and is a 1.5 mile hike east from the Hobble Creek Campground. Lake Alice provides beautiful views, fishing and a variety of hiking and horseback opportunities to visitors. Visitors are strongly encouraged to practice clean camping techniques and to store attractants (e.g. food, toothpaste) in a manner that makes them unavailable to bears.

name: GEISINGER
description: Geisinger Campground is located at the entrance to Upper Priest Lake. It has three sites at the confluence with the Thorofare, all furnished with fire rings, picnic tables, and bear-proof storage boxes.Please note that this campground has a Pack it In, Pack It Out policy on all garbage.

name: BOONES RUN MASSANUTTEN SHELTER
description: This is a primitive Trail Shelter

name: Haymeadow Camping Area
description: HAYMEADOW CAMPING AREA (Camping Area)

name: Summit Lake Campground
description: SUMMIT LAKE CAMPGROUND (Campground)

name: BIG BAR
description: This is a large dispersed camping area along the Snake River in Hells Canyon. There are no formal parking or camping units. The camping area is used by both tent campers and RVs. Few amenities exist. There is one outhouse and informational sign near the entrance. Allison Creek Trailhead is across the Hells Canyon Road with access to Allison Creek Trail (#514).

name: CLOVER MEADOW
description: Shaded by Lodge pole pine and Fir trees, Clover Meadow Campground is located along Clover Meadow. The campground provides picnic tables and fire rings. Access road is closed in winter and the nearby Clover Meadow Station is also closed seasonally.

name: ELIZA BROOK SHELTER
description: Eliza Brook Shelter and 4 hardened tent pads are located near Eliza Brook off Kinsman Ridge Trail (Appalachian Trail) 2.5 miles south of the South Kinsman summit on the mountain's southern ridge. A composting privy, bear box, and dishwashing area are provided. The site is visited by a roving caretaker.

name: 25 Mile Camping Area
description: 25 MILE CAMPING AREA (Camping Area)

name: BIG CREEK CAMPGROUND
description: Several dispersed camping sites on Big Creek. No services available, pack in/pack out.

name: Crestline
description: 50 person capacity.

name: BUCK CREEK
description: This is a campground on the Powers to Glendale Bike Route. It is six miles to the Panther Ridge Trail #1253, which leads to Hanging Rock. ; Facilities2 campsites with picnic tables, and fire pitsNo drinking waterVault toiletNo garbage disposal - Please pack it out

name: Ohmer Creek Campground
description: The Ohmer Creek Campground is on a minimal maintenance schedule due to budget constraints. Please pack in/pack out your trash and use restroom facilities at neighboring Forest Service recreation areas if a waste containment system is not available on your camping unit.

name: GRAVE CREEK
description: Grave Creek Campground is located 4 miles north of Fortine on road 7061. The campground has 4 campsites with tables and fire rings and able to accommodate up to a 20' rd. Amenities include vault toilets.

name: Lakeside
description: LAKESIDE (Campground) is permanently closed

name: Willie Lee
description: The trailhead at Willie Lee provides access to the Bateman Trail system from the east. It is nearby the Wolf Junction dispersed camping area. The site is not developed, but dispersed camping opportunities are limited. This location is also stop #6 on the Glade Top Trail Scenic Byways tour. The 1930s plat book shows J.W. Findley as the owner of the land now known as Wolf Junction. Other individuals owned the land before Mr. Findley, but he left a lasting impression that is part of Ozarks history. Mr. Findley was a noted author, local historian, and was known as the walking preacher of the Ozarks. In his retirement, J.W. Findley wrote 8 books, each relating to the Missouri Ozarks. He was 92 years old when he died in 1990 while living in Ava, MO. You can tell by the following quote that J.W. Findley was fond of the Ozarks: "And when Indian Summer comes and God hangs a shimmering curtain of blue purple over these Ozark Hills, and the trees put on their robes of scarlet and gold, just take a drive over the Glade Top (Skyline) drive and you'll say you've seen a little bit of Ozark Glory, too. God must have loved our hills a lot, or He wouldn't have made so many of them." (Ozark Glory,1985 J.W. Findley)The White River Historical Society located in Forysyth, MO was very helpful in gathering information for this stop. If you would like to learn more about Taney County history, visit their website http://wrvhs.org/. According to the 1930s plat book, lands now known as Willie Lee were once owned by the Rialto Land and Mining Co. in the 30s. The company owned several acres of land in the immediate area. Research has not found much information regarding this company.

name: NEMO CAMPSITE
description: Entry and Information site for the Nemo Campsites on Wrangell Island. Site is occupied by Wrangell Island Host Volunteers, and used for evening campground programs in the summer months. Available for camping when not occupied by island hosts. Information boards provide posted information for the public.

name: FISH LAKE
description: Fish Lake Campground is remote and at a high elevation location. It offers 5 walk-in tent-only sites near a small lake and the Cle Elum River. There is no fee and no services. Pack out your trash.

name: Barn Hollow Float Camp
description: Barn Hollow Float Camp is on the left bank of the Eleven Point National Scenic River. This camp is located 10.4 miles downriver of Greer Crossing. Access is by river only. Canoes may be launched anywhere upstream but the closest accesses are  Turner Mill  about 5 miles and McDowell Primitive Access about 2 miles above Barn Hollow. The nearest takeout point below this camp is  Whitten Access , about 1.3 miles.

name: Clark Peak Corrals
description: Clark Peak Corrals Dispersed Camping, located close to 9,000 feet in mixed-conifer forest, is the last dispersed camping area at the end of National Forest Service (NFS) Road 803 beyond the Swift Trail. It is 34.5 miles from Swift Trail Junction at the intersection of AZ 366/Swift Trail and US 191. This area has two established dispersed campsites and public corrals. There are no restrooms or trash cans. Please be prepared to pack out all your waste. Refer to our Dispersed Camping page for more information and dispersed camping best practices. This area serves primarily as a trailhead for the surrounding area. Vehicles (including trailers) longer than 22 feet are not recommended because of the difficulty of negotiating the switchbacks on AZ 366. This trailhead is not accessible from November 15 to April 15 when the Swift Trail is closed for the winter. Early or late snow may extend the inaccessible season.

name: COPPER KING CAMPGROUND
description: This campground is in a moist river bottom cedar forest (bring your bug repellent in June and July). Adjacent Thompson River offers fishing opportunities. Access for large vehicles can be challenging.

name: Nelder Grove
description: Sites are located along California Creek. Good shade provided by pine and fir trees. Located near Bull Buck Trail. Parking Lot; restroom; historical sites; nature trails.Beyond the campsite there are various giant sequoia trees that you can visit. We advise everyone to stay on the trail, and to stay behind the fences guarding the trees preserving their beauty for the future generations. This summer we are expecting a large number of visitors so please plan for delays, thank you.

name: PAUL GERHARD TUSCARORA SHELTER
description: This is a primitive Trail Shelter

name: Cebolla Mesa
description: Camping - fivesites and picnicking. Fishing -1 mile down on the Rio Grande River and Red River. Hiking - Trailhead for Rio Grande wild and Scenic River, Trail #102.

name: Blacks Pond
description:
A campground on the Ashland Ranger District.
Camp sites: 2
Potable Water: No
Trash Pickup: No
Firewood: No

name: MCDONALD FLAT CAMPGROUND
description: 5400-foot elevation. 6 campsites along Panther Creek. Fishing for wily trout in Panther Creek. 20-foot maximum trailer length.

name: Bear Creek Cg
description: Bear Creek Transfer Camp is located 32 miles north of Fairfield. The transfer camp offers 6 campsites with picnic tables and fire rings along with corrals and mangers with loading ramps and stock water available 150 yards to the north at Bear Creek. There is one vault toilet restroom available.

name: BEAR CREEK HUNT CAMP
description: The Bear Creek Hunt Camp is a three-sided shelter available for free public use.  There is a picnic table and fire ring located onsite.  There is a fourteen day stay limit within a 30 day period at this shelter.

name: HELLER CREEK
description: Heller Creek Campground features 4 camp units and vault toilets. Please observe the Pack it In Pack it Out refuse policy. There is no potable water. Attractions include fishing, hiking, the St. Joe Wild and Scenic River, and Heller gravesite.

name: Borrego Mesa
description: The Borrego Mesa Campground is located close to several trailheads leading into the north half of the Pecos Wilderness. Amenitites include picnic tables, firepits and small corrals at each site suitable for one or two horses. The Vaulted toilet is currently not in service. Adjacent to and south of the campground is the Rio Medio Trailhead, one of the major trailheads into the Pecos Wilderness. The campground is rather primitive and little used, and is much less developed than most. It is primarily used for picnicking by locals from nearby communities, and also serves those who use it for an overnight stay before embarking on a horsepack or backpack into the Pecos.There is ample space for trailer/RV camping, but no dump station is available. There is no potable water and no Campground Host.

name: ALGOMA CG-F
description: Located on the Upper McCloud River at an elevation of 3800 feet, this is a small undeveloped camping area with 8 user-created sites and a vault toilet. No drinking water. No fee. 15 day stay limit. Features: Algoma is the terminus of the McCloud River Trail, a distance of 15 miles from Lower Falls. This area receives less traffic than the more popular McCloud River Loop, offering a quieter riverside camping experience.

name: Toad Lake Cg
description: This campground has six campsites along the stream 1/2 mile below the outlet of Toad Lake.  A popular lake with fair fishing for mostly small Brook Trout, and some Rainbow Trout as well. Shores vary from timber to rocks and meadows. The fly fishing can be excellent. Many sensitive and rare plants are found in this location, and it is an excellent nature walk area.  Boats are not allowed.

name: Silver Creek T.H.
description: Small campground allowing access to North Fork Silver Creek Trail #119 and South Fork Silver Creek Trail #123.

name: Pine Creek Campground
description: Situated on the eastern side of the Toquima Mountain Range in the Monitor Valley. Fishing in Peavine Creek. Two trailheads with access to Arc Dome Wilderness at the end of Forest Road 020. The trail from Peavine trailhead leads up Peavine Canyon to connect with the Toiyabe Crest tiol Recreation Trail. The trail from Toms Canyon follows Toms Creek to the Toiyabe Crest tiol Recreation Trail. Hiking: trails lead to Mt. Jefferson in the Alta Toquima Wilderness Area and also to Arc Dome Wilderness. Places to visit are Arc Dome Wilderness, Alta Toquima Wilderness Area, Dia 's Punch Bowl, the towns of Belmont and Manhattan. Pets should be kept on leash. 21 units and 1 group.

name: Buckhead Mountain
description: Buckhead Mountain Camping Area offers a rustic camping experience under the stars. Right at the border of the Tiller Ranger District and Diamond Lake District. Enjoy a day in the shade of some old trees or go on an adventure as nearby roads take you to other recreation sites across the forest. This camping area is located just off Forest Service Road 702.

name: LAKE SANTEETLAH CAMPSITES
description: Dispersed campsites located in the Santeetlah Lake watershed.  Each campsite has a fire ring, picnic table and lantern post.  There is a fourteen day stay limit within a 30 day period at each campsite.

name: TELICHPAH
description: Telichpah Campground features 5 camp units and vault toilets. Please observe the Pack it In, Pack it Out refuse policy. There is no potable water. Trailers are not recommended. Attractions include fishing on the North Fork St. Joe River and nearby streams.

name: FLY FLAT
description: Fly Flat Campground features 14 camp units, drinking water (June-October), and vault toilets. Please comply with the Pack it In Pack it Out refuse policy. Attractions include fishing in wild trout waters, St. Joe Wild and Scenic River, and the Fly Creek Trailhead.

name: BUCK ROCK CAMPGROUND
description: This campground sits at 7,600 feet elevation. It is nearby to Big Meadow Creek, Buck Rock Lookout, and trails into Jennie Lakes wilderness.  At Hume Lake, approximately 15 miles away, visitors enjoy swimming, non-motorized boating, fishing and hiking. The trails in the district are open to hikers, horses and bikes (however, bikes are not permitted in wilderness areas).Facilities: This campground has a picnic table and campfire ring at each site. This is bear country and proper food storage is required. There is also no trash services, so pack it in pack it out. Leave no trace principals apply. Standard amenity fee is collected as part of an interagency agreement with the National Park Service.

name: Big Blue Campground
description: A real jewel of a secluded campground overlooking a picturesque valley adjacent to the Uncompahgre Wilderness. Located near the junction of Soldier Creek and Blue Creek with variety of hiking trails exist in the area including Big Blue Trail, Fall Creek Trail, Ridge Stock Driveway Trail and Alpine Trail. Most of these trails lead south into the wilderness where mechanized and motorized travel is not allowed. The landscape is mostly aspen and spruce trees. This is bear country, must practice safe food storage techniques.

name: Sample Meadow
description: Located near the Kaiser and Ansel Adams Wilderness ', Sample Meadow Campground offers 16 campsites located along Kaiser Creek. Vault toilets are provided and each site has a picnic table, fire ring, and bear box. There is trailhead parking outside of campground approximately .5 mile for hikes into the wilderness. Large RV 's and motorhomes not recommended. Horse camping is permitted. Water and garbage service not provided.

name: TOLL MOUNTAIN CAMPGROUND
description: Toll Mountain campground is located on the eastside of the Highland Mountain Range, approximately 20 miles east of Butte. The campground has 5 units that will accommodate trailers up to 22 feet and also has a group picnic area. The campground is close to a creek and offers a quiet forest setting for weekend getaways.

name: GRASSY RANCH
description: Located at the edge of the Boulder Creek Wilderness, Grassy Ranch Camping Area provides visitors with a quiet and secluded opportunity to camp and relax.

name: FISH CREEK
description: CLOSED DUE TO RIVERSIDE FIRE Fish Creek Campground is located next to the Clackamas Wild and Scenic River. It provides access to some of the area ' s whitewater, as well as a place to fish. Whether it is relaxation or expansive exploration, there ' s something for everyone at Fish Creek.

name: LOWER HONDO
description: One of three small sites on paved road to Taos Ski Valley providing access to fishing on Rio Hondo and hiking in Columbine-Hondo Wilderness Study Area and Wheeler Peak Wilderness.

name: Sylvia Lake Campground
description: Sylvia Lake Campground has 3 designated campsites.  Each site has a picnic table, fire ring, and bear box. There is a vault toilet in the campground.  There is a small steel and timber boat ramp to assist in launching canoes and kayaks.  The lake has native grayling and cutthroat trout.

name: Middle Mountain Shelter
description: MIDDLE MOUNTAIN SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: REDBANK
description: There are 5 campsites at Red Bank campground situated right on the North Fork of the Salmon River.

name: Red Shale
description: A campground on the Ashland Ranger District.

name: Rio De Los Pinos Cg
description: 4 developed campsites   dispersed camping at 8000 ' with superb river fishing access just west of NM Game and Fish Recreation Area

name: Rock Creek South
description: ROCK CREEK SOUTH (Campground)

name: Peru Peak Shelter
description: overnight shelter located on the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and coincident Long Trail

name: Fairview Cg
description: Fairview Camp is drive-through loop off State Highway 207 offering five campsites and an accessible vault toilet. Two campsites directly across from the toilet are fully accessible. A free-flowing water fountain provides potable water from May to October. Remnants from a wildfire in the late 1980s can be seen along the egdes of this small campground. There is no garbage service, so please pack out all garbage and dispose of it at home.The campground is used primarily for hunting and OHV riding--its trailhead accesses 80 miles of OHV roads and trails on the Heppner Ranger District. ; Also,; Morrow County OHV Park is only 6 miles north on State Highway 207 and offers over 200 miles of OHV marked and groomed trails. ; The main season of use is from late fall to early winter during big game hunting season. ; It also serves as an overflow camping site when Bull Prairie Lake Campground is at full capacity.

name: Clearwater Crossing Campground
description: Off the beaten path, this is a small campground with stock facilities and public corrals. The nearby trailhead is primarily used for horseback riding and hiking into the Great Burn area.

name: CORRAL CREEK
description: Dispersed camping and day use site along the North Fork of the Kern River. Portable toilets and trash bins available during summer months. No water available. Small, short trail leads to Corral Creek Picnic Area, which is a small beach along the Kern River. Camping, dogs, vehicles, and campfires are not allowed on beach. Dispersed Camping Rules, Regulations, and Tips

name: JACK CREEK CAMPGROUND
description: Generally open May to November as weather and conditions allow. Campground is situated in a beautiful, historic area. Sites are in an open cottonwood area. Please pack out all your trash. This campground can fill up during hunting season.

name: Sisters Cow Camp
description: Maintained and operated in cooperation with the Central Oregon Chapter of Oregon Equestrian Trails, this five site campground offers early season access to the Metolius Windigo Trail. Please note: Horse campgrounds have been designed to accommodate people who need to corral their horses. We have a limited number of these kinds of campgrounds and ask, out of courtesy and safety for you and the horses, to please consider camping elsewhere if you do not have a horse. We have many campgrounds nearby.

name: Red Dirt Reservoir Camground
description: LOCATION:Red Dirt Reservoir is located in the Gore Pass area off HWY134 in the Routt National Forest. It is approximately 40 miles east of Yampa in between the towns of Yampa and Kremmling.DESCRIPTION:Small area offering dispersed camping at the reservoir and rainbow trout fishing. Red Dirt Reservoir is managed by the Yampa Ranger District.RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES: Fishing, hiking, mountain biking, and scenery viewing.KNOW BEFORE YOU GO: The area was burned in 2018 by the Silver Creek Fire so visitors can expect to still see a burn scar. Please be aware of snags and do not camp under dead, burned trees for your safety.  SERVICES: 1 vault toilet, no potable water, no trash serviceCAMPING TRAILER USE: For those traveling with trailers, beware there are no pull-throughs which can make turning around difficult depending on the traffic and usage of others during your stay.  FIRE RESTRICTIONS: Fire bans and restrictions can take place at any time. Please check with the Yampa Ranger Station prior to arrival for current restrictions970-638-4516

name: Bell Farm Horse Camp
description: Bell Farm Horse Camp is located off Road 1363 in McCreary County and is a popular place for wagon train riders who come to "rest a spell."  In the early 1900s, this area was a logging and mining town. In the 1930s, it transitioned into a Civilian Conservation Corps camp. Rock Creek, a Kentucky Wild River, runs alongside the camp. The camp features five group campsites suitable for 10-15 people per site. All sites have fire rings, picnic tables, lantern posts and tent pads. Stock water can be collected from Rock Creek.

name: Red Bridge River Access Site
description: The name comes from an old wooden and steel bridge, painted red, that was located at the site. Now there is a modern cement structure. This site provides access to the Manistee River Trail. There is designated parking for vehicles with boat trailers at Red Bridge. There is also parking available at Upper River Road Trailhead for hikers.

name: BIGFLAT
description: Big Flat Trailhead is the starting point for popular hikes to the Trinity Alps Wilderness including Caribou Lakes. The Big Flat campground is adjacent and has 9 campsites. There is no potable water or garbage service provided, but there are vault toilets in the campground. Due to elevation, accessibility determined by snow levels.

name: Grapevine Bay
description: This site is located along the shoreline of central Arizona's largest lake. The setting is in the Upper Sonoran Desert. Vegetation includes mesquite, cat-claw, desert broom, cholla, and saguaro cacti. This site provides a spectacular view of the Sierra Ancha Mountains.  Use trash receptacles when available or Pack it in, Pack it out. This area is prone to flash floods. Camp out of flood areas and watch the weather carefully.

name: Head of the Ditch
description: HEAD OF THE DITCH (Campground)

name: MAGRUDER CROSSING CAMPGROUND
description: Magruder Crossing Campground features 6 campsites on the Selway River, and a vault toilet. Site will accept RVs or trailers to 30. Stock can be kept in this campground. This was the crossing on a route established for commerce between Lewiston and Virginia City, MT during the gold rush. To the north of the campground, an earlier route, Southern Nez Perce Trail, crosses the road.

name: Little Jimmy
description: Just above Crystal Lake lies Little Jimmy trail camp provides a backcountry campground nestled just 2 miles off the Angeles Crest Highway. It features seven first-come, first-served sites with picnic tables, fire rings, vault/composting toilets, and vintage backcountry ovens.

name: ROBINSON FLAT
description: Robinson Flat Campground is a remote campground under pines and firs near a beautiful meadow and stream. The campground is the last stop of the Foresthill Divide Road Driving Tour. Seven family sites and seven equestrian sites located 27 miles northeast of Foresthill at an elevation of 6,800 feet. This campground has vault toilets and a hand pump well nearby. There is no trash removal service so pack out what you pack in. The road to the campground is narrow and winding so trailers are not recommended. This campground is located on the Western States Trail.

name: Evans Creek Campground
description: Evans Creek Campground is located along Anderson Ranch Reservoir. There are 10 first come first serve campsites.

name: Jones Water Campground
description: Jones Water is a small primitive site nestled in a riparian area. It is an ideal dispersed camping site that allows for a fun weekend getaway. Many desert animals can be spotted at this camping site. Bird watchers enjoy this location because of the abundance of native bird species that can spotted for the campgrounds.

name: Cedar Pass
description: CEDAR PASS (Campground)

name: Shields River
description: A campground in the Shields River drainage of the West Crazy Mountains on the Yellowstone District.  Pack in/pack out trash, no water is available.

name: West Fork
description: 3,100-feet in elevation Hike-in site with seven trailside campsites. When open, this site is not regularly maintained. The Gabrielino National Recreation Trail and Silver Moccasin National Recreation Trail intersect just south of the camp. California Campfire Permit is required--only valid when fire restrictions allow--and may be obtained online or at any Forest Service office.

name: Hercules Tower Trailhead
description: Hercules Glades ? a combination of open grassland, forested knobs, steep rocky hillsides, and narrow drainages ? offers unusual beauty and a measure of solitude within easy reach of wilderness lovers.  The area is characterized by shallow, droughty soils and limestone rock outcroppings and glades.  The term glades refer to the bald top hills found in the wilderness.  The result is a prairie ecosystem that looks more like what you would find hundreds of miles to the west? Dry land grasses spotted with cedar trees.  In addition, the prairies have changed the makeup of the local forest.  Rather than the typical oak and hickory assemblage, cedars are pervasive.  Although oaks are ever present in the forest, cedars are sometimes the dominant species.

name: Elk Canoe Backcountry Campsites
description: This campground is located in the middle of the 66-mile Scenic portion of the river. The camps are set back from the river in openings within a forested setting. As paddlers travel down the river they will see many meadows and locations to fish. Some campers will park at Upper Branch Bridge and walk to the campsites from there. This is a very popular fishing area.

name: Williams Lake Campground
description: WILLIAMS LAKE CAMPGROUND (Campground)

name: WILEY FLAT
description: This rustic campground in the Maury Mountains surrounds Wiley Creek, which is a shallow, narrow body of water ending at the small meadow within the perimeter of the camp. It is not uncommon to see horseback riders stopping for a noon break from a local outfitter guide service.

name: Upper Canyon Creek
description: The campground of dispersed units is set in a mature stand of Ponderosa pine with a mix of white and Douglas fir. Canyon Creek is popular among anglers fishing for rainbow trout. The Arizona Game and Fish Department Canyon Creek Fish Hatchery is nearby. Wildlife includes: Abert squirrel, black bear. Pack it in & Pack it out, no trash services. 14-day stay limit. Trailers must be under 16 feet.

name: Judith Station Campground
description: Judith Station Day Use Area is located in the Helena-Lewis and Clark National Forest, adjacent to the historic Judith Guard Station. Amenities include nearby fishing access, drinking water, and a restroom.Bears may frequent the area; keep all food out of sight in approved containers and remove all food from area after eating. Mandatory food storage is required.

name: Rocky Canyon
description: ROCKY CANYON (Campground)

name: Bear Canyon Lake Cg
description: A beautiful, narrow, canyon-bound lake, accessible by foot trail only,Bear Canyon Lake is one of several in a series of fishing lakes built by Arizona Game and Fish Department. Despite being several miles down a dirt road and having few amenities, it draws many visitors. The partially developed campground which is set among the mixed conifer, oak and aspen, has only limited amenities.Bear Canyon Lake is a  'Pack it in - Pack it out ' area. There is NO GARBAGE SERVICE. Please be good stewards of the land and leave the area better than how you found it.For purposes of fire restrictions, this campground is considered to be an  'undeveloped ' campground. No fires will be permitted when fire restrictions are in effect for the Apache-Sitgreaves Forest.At an elevation of 7,560, Bear Canyon Lake consists of 60 surface acres with a maximum depth of 50 feet. Because of its depth, this lake has no water quality problems. The Arizona Department of Game and Fish stocks it with catchable-sized rainbow trout about six times each year.Arizona fishing regulations apply. Please refer to the current year fishing regulations brochure produced by the Arizona Game and Fish Department for further details on licensing requirements, daily bag limits, and other restrictions. Boat motors are restricted to electric motors only.

name: Domke Lake
description: This area is currently for day use only. Domke Lake, Stuart Camp, and Hatchery Camp are closed for overnight camping due to post fire hazards caused by the 2015 Wolverine fire. There are three small hike in campgrounds surrounding Domke Lake offering a total of eight tent-only sites.

name: Orogrande (1-2)
description: Locally known as Orogrande #1 and 2, this campground occupies both sides of the road, one on the bank of Crooked River. It includes a toilet, fire rings and at least three camp pads. The non-river side is a good spot for one family or small group. The river side is an open, grassy campsite.

name: Paint River Forks Campground
description: This campground is a small rural campground that offers river bank camping. Located at the fork of the South and North Branch of the Paint River it offers canoeing and fishing opportunities.

name: Jack Creek
description: Developed campground with picnic tables, grills, fire rings

name: DENNY CG-F
description: This remote campground has 5 first come first served sites and has a steep trail down to the New River.  There are vault toilets but no water.

name: Summit
description: Summit camping area is a great place for those who enjoy rustic camping. Toilets, water, and garbage service are not provided at this site. The site contains one picnic table and rock fire ring.

name: Sheridan Creek
description: Snow Oval is a popular dispersed camping area and also serves as a popular staging area for both OHV and OSV use. This camping area is located within the foothills of Wind River mountains north of Dubois, Wyoming.  The Snow Oval has ample parking, bear boxes, a vault toilet, and visitor information.  There is a 16-day stay limit and food storage is required per the Shoshone tiol Forest Food Storage Order.

name: Plum Valley Campground
description: PLUM VALLEY CAMPGROUND (Campground)

name: Clear Creek Cg-F
description: Clear Creek campground is a small remote facility with only 6 campsites. It can accommodate a trailer up to 22 feet and offers picnic tables, fire rings and a vault toilet.

name: Bob Scott Campground
description: Generally open May to October as weather and conditions allow. Accessible from U.S. Route 50.In open setting with pinyon-juniper forest at Bob Scott Summit. Hunting for deer and elk in season. Fishing at Birch Creek, 8 miles from campground.

name: EAST CREEK CAMPGROUND
description: Get high on life at this small, high-elevation campground in the Montana mountains with 4 camping units. East Creek Campground offers first-come, first-served sites for tents or small trailers. There is no cell phone service here so you can truly unplug and let the wilderness take all your cares away. Immerse yourself in the outdoors, and find your happy place here with minimal distractions. Campers often rave about the views from this site.

name: CEDAR CAMP
description: Located in a timber area of mature fir and pine. Access up Trough Ridge or Little Stony Road is not recommended for trailers. CURRENTLY CLOSED

name: Ojo Redondo
description: OJO REDONDO (Campground)

name: LAKE NUMBER 3
description: The Lake No. 3 dispersed camping area is named for the lake that one of the sites overlooks. This small camping area has 2 hardened campsites, fire rings and picnic tables available for visitors looking for a more secluded camping area. Special Features: Lake No. 3 dispersed campsite is a nice, small site without a lot of amenities. It is within a mile of the Salt Chuck Trail , which brings hikers to an interesting abandoned copper mine site. The campsite is also close to Lake Ellen and No. 3 Lake. Many visitors hike down to these lakes to swim or fish for trout and Dolly Varden. The second growth stands nearby are good spots to pick berries and may offer opportunities to see deer and bears.

name: HOLIDAY SPRING
description:
A campground on the Ashland Ranger District.
Camp sites: 3
Trash Pickup: No
Firewood: No
Potable Water: No

name: BLACK BEAR CAMPGROUND
description: Located on the banks of Skalkaho Creek, Black Bear Campground hosts 6 sites with picnic tables, fire rings, and a vault toilet. There is no garbage service so Pack it in/Pack it out. Campground can accommodate RVs or trailers to 50.

name: Thirteen Falls
description: THIRTEEN FALLS (Campground)

name: Annie Creek Sno-Park
description: Annie Creek Sno-Park is located 43 miles northwest of Klamath Falls, Oregon, near the Crater Lake National Park boundary. Its proximity is rich with history, as Fort Klamath lies less than 10 miles from the Sno-Park. Fort Klamath was established as a military outpost on the Oregon Trail in 1863. Today, it's listed on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places. If you want a break from recreating, it's convenient to visit the Fort Klamath park and museum. Annie Creek offers more amenities than the average Sno-Park. As an official stop on the Oregon Volcanic Scenic Byway, you'll find an interpretive kiosk, as well as two vaulted toilets. An attractive log-style warming shelter with wood stove and benches is open year round for picnics and relaxation. Snowmobilers can enjoy cruising under snow covered ponderosa pines and accessing miles and miles of trails. There are no managed cross country ski trails from Annie Creek. Besides snowmobiling, winter enthusiasts of all ages flock to Annie Creek Sno-Park for excellent sledding opportunities. Adjacent to the warming shelter lies a huge bowl shaped hill perfect for coasting your sled down. At an elevation of 4,400 feet, Annie Creek generally sees snow from late November through February. There is no potable water. Visitors need to bring plenty of water.

name: SAMS CREEK
description: Sam's Creek Campground, near the Gospel-Hump Wilderness on Crooked Creek and Sams Creek, is peacefully tucked in among a grove of  pine trees with the soothing sounds of the river running in the background. Three campsites, tables and fire grates allow for relaxed camping. There is limited parking and limited maneuvering for camp trailers.

name: Big Eightmile Campground/Trailhead
description: 10 campsites with picnic tables and fire rings on Big Eightmile Creek.

name: TOQUIMA CAVE CAMPGROUND
description: Generally open May to October as weather and conditions allow. The big attraction here is, of course, the caves. The half-mile Cave trail begins in the campground, with a series of stone steps leading to the rock shelter site. The red, yellow, black and white images (pictographs) here were painted by ancient Shoshones. Projectile points found at this cave date to about 600-1300 CE. On nearby BLM land is Spencers Hot Springs. The water is 192 degrees, and there is a developed tub and a below-ground pool. 2 units NO group.

name: Dry Fork Camping Area
description: DRY FORK CAMPING AREA (Camping Area)

name: BOUNDARY SPRING
description: A quiet campground dominated by lodgepole and ponderosa pine trees and predominantly used by the ATV and hunting communities. This site is located on the southeast edge of the district.

name: Little Fort
description: Little Fort is a minimally developed recreation area located near a meadow that was once a rest stop for a stagecoach line. Enjoy the thrill of riding the largest OHV system in the state of Virginia with easy access right from the campground to the Peters Mill Run/Taskers Gap OHV trail system.

name: Sagehen Creek
description: Sagehen Creek Campground

name: Pavlak Campground
description: Generally, open June to October as weather and conditions allow.

name: EAST TOWER
description: EAST TOWER CAMPGROUND

name: LITTLE JACKASS
description: Shaded by oak and pine trees, Little Jackass Campground is a small campground that offers campsites along Fish Creek. Each site has a table, grill and fire ring and the campground provides one vault toilet. Closest service is Wagner '||chr(39)||'s Store.

name: BEAR CREEK
description: A campground in the West Absaroka Mountains on Gardiner District. *No vehicle access due to flood-related damage.  Bear Creek  is a primitive campground and is only accessible by walking a short distance to the campground. Contact district for info.

name: MILL FLAT CAMPGROUND
description: Located at 1,100-foot elevation. Five campsites on the Kings Wild and Scenic River. Rafting is popular on the river, with up to Class III rapids. The region offers trails for hikers, horses, and bikes (outside the wilderness areas), wind  up mountains, and alongside wild rivers. Unsuitable for trailers, no drinking water is available. Special food storage rule in effect because this is black bear country. Check current fire restrictions before venturing out. Leave no trace principals apply.

name: Willow Creek Campground
description: Willow Creek Campground is located on the middle fork of the Boise River.  There are nine first come first serve campsites.

name: LYMAN LAKE
description: This dispersed site; is a small, primitive campground with 4 campsites next to Lyman Lake. Each campsite has a picnic table and fire ring. Three campsites are located near the 2 pit toilets and 1 is located across the lake. No water or garbage service. Please pack out garbage.

name: BUTTE CREEK
description: Quiet and off the beaten path, Butte Creek campground is located 4 miles off Highway 44. No fee.

name: Langford Lake Camp
description: LANGFORD LAKE CAMP (Campground)

name: JENNINGS CAMP CAMPGROUND
description: This campground is located on the banks of the East Fork of the Bitterroot river. It has 4 campsites with picnic tables, fire rings and an accessible vault toilet. Site will accept RVs or trailers to 20.

name: Eightmile Camping Area
description: EIGHTMILE CAMPING AREA (Camping Area)

name: Bear Pen Shelter
description: BEAR PEN SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: AIRPORT FLAT CG
description: Sites are arranged into pods to accommodate groups of 15 - 25 people.

name: Marijuana Flat
description: Closed

name: MCDOUGLE
description: McDougal Camp is a hunt camp available for primitive camping.

name: SOUTH VAN HOUTEN CAMPGROUND
description: This campground is located across the lake from North Van Houten Campground and surrounded by lodgepole pine.

name: HALFWAY HOUSE
description: Halfway House Campground rests in tall timber with a small creek running through. There are campsites with tables and fire rings. Stock facilities (feed bunk and loading ramp) are nearby. This is a popular access site into the Gospel Hump Wilderness Area via Crooked Creek Trail #215.

name: EMILY PROCTOR SHELTER & TENT AREA
description: Shelter and tent area located on the Long Trail in Breadloaf Wilderness.

name: Harris Springs Cg-F
description: This is an undeveloped camping area located approximately 15 miles north of Highway 89. There are about 15 user-created sites and a vault toilet. Bring your own drinking water.  This is near the site of an historic guard station. The guard station, which is essentially a cabin, has been restored by the Forest Service, but is no longer part of the Lookouts and Cabins Rental Program. This camp is very popular with hunters in the fall hunting season.

name: HEAD OF THE RIVER
description: Located 50 minutes northeast of Chiloquin, OR, Head of the River Campground is a rustic forest camp situated at the headwaters of the; Williamson River at the base of the hillside. The pure, spring-fed river flows by the rustic campground. There are five campsites and one vaulted toiled. ; Amenities include picnic tables and camp fire rings. June and July are heavy mosquito months, so bring bug spray. There are no official trails for hiking at Head of the River, but you can walk down to the bank. Fly-fishing opportunities abound nearby; check the State of Oregon fishing regulations for precise locations. Head of the River is a popular campground for hunters in the fall. There is no potable water. Visitors need to bring an adequate supply of water.

name: LONG BOTTOM FORD
description: Also commonly referred to as "Low Water Bridge Campground", this quiet primitive campground is located on the banks of the Chattooga River with fishing, boating, and tubing opportunities nearby. It is open year-round with no charge and site amenities include trash cans, fire rings, and a vault toilet.

name: SLIDE CREEK CG-F
description: Slide Creek Campground is has 5 tent only camp units. There is no water system.

name: Cooley Glen Shelter
description: Shelter located on the Long Trail in Breadloaf Wilderness.

name: Five Points Cg
description: Five Points Campground is a primitive campground composed of 7 units located near Five Points Creek 17 miles north of Fairfield over Couch Summit. The newly renovated campground offers restrooms and is close to the popular Worswick hot springs. Potable water is not available at this campground.

name: Upper Hospital Flat
description:
Upper Hospital Flat Dispersed Camping Area is a great place to escape the summer heat of surrounding deserts and retreat to a scenic meadow in the Pinale?o Mountains of southeastern Arizona. The area is known for camping, scenic driving, picnicking, birding, wildlife viewing, hiking, mountain biking, and history. There are no amenities at this site. Refer to our Dispersed Camping page for more information and dispersed camping best practices.
Hospital Flat is so named because in the 1880s it served as a site for a field hospital for ailing soldiers from Fort Grant. That frontier outpost is located along Grant Creek on the south slope of the Pinale?os. The restorative powers of this cool mountain meadow, carpeted with wildflowers and traversed by a small creek, were sufficiently notable that it also became a summer retreat for officers and their families trying to escape the heat of their desert outpost. Fort Grant was closed in 1905 and now serves as an Arizona State Prison Facility. Hospital Flat still serves as a popular refuge for forest recreationists who come to its pleasant surroundings for much the same reason as those soldiers.
Note: Black bear area. Store and dispose of all food in bear-proof containers and trash bins, or keep it locked in your vehicle. Vehicles (including trailers) longer than 22 feet are not recommended because of the difficulty of negotiating the switchbacks on AZ 366. This dispersed camping area is not accessible by vehicle from November 15 to April 15 when the Swift Trail is closed for the winter. Early or late snow may extend the inaccessible season.

name: Sucker Brook Shelter
description: Trail shelter located on the North Country Trail and Long Trail in the Joseph Battell Wilderness.  3 sided Lean-to with privy on site

name: HOTELLING
description: Hoteling campground has 4 campsites right on the South Fork of the Salmon River. Easy access makes it a popular destination all summer long with the locals.

name: Ice Springs Campground
description: Ice Springs Campground has 3 campsites on Fall Creek near Anderson Ranch Reservoir

name: Baja
description: BAJA (Campground)

name: Hazel Creek
description: Hazel Creek is in a remote area without cell phone service. This primitive campground is popular with OHV/ATV riders, equestrians, and mountain bikers. There is a trailhead for the Ozark Trail is on the road leading into the campground. Hazel Creek is part of the Old Lead Belt, where much of the nation lead ore was once mined. This site features a foundation from a historic lead smelter. The Trail of Tears National Historic Trail goes through the site.

name: THREE PONDS SHELTER
description: This three sided Adirondack Shelter near Rumney NH  is a first come first served facility that is free of charge.  The  2.3 mile trail leading to the shelter is a snowmobile trail but skiers, snowshoers and winer hikers are all  welcome.

name: Barrel Springs
description: BARREL SPRINGS (Campground)

name: BIG SLIDE CG-F
description: This facility has 8 tent only camping sites and offers access to swimming, fishing and hiking. No potable water.

name: Trout Creek Campground
description: TROUT CREEK CAMPGROUND (Campground)

name: Horseshoe Lake (Olallie)
description: CLOSED DUE TO FIRE: Sites south of the Olallie Lake, including Peninsula CG, Horseshoe Lake CG, and Skyline Rd, suffered extensive damage in Lionshead Fire and subsequent winter storm blowdown and will NOT reopen this year. Located on the high and lovely Horseshoe Lake. Located just south of Monon Lake in the Olallie Scenic Area, Horseshoe Lake Campground is sandwiched between the shoreline of Horseshoe Lake and NF-4220. Due to the area 's remote nature, although the campsites are just off of NF-4220, few vehicles pass by which makes this outdoor recreation area so special. The lake, as the name might imply, is horseshoe-shaped with a small channel leading to the lake's southern half. Recreational activities include hiking, fishing, and non-motorized boating.

name: LITTLE ROARING RIVER LAKE CAMPGROUND
description: LITTLE ROARING RIVER LAKE CAMPGROUND

name: Gold Creek Campground
description: 4 campsites with extensive hiking, biking, motorcycle and horseback riding opportunities. Trails from the campground and from near the campground access the Skalkaho Wildlife Preserve, Gold Creek, and the Easthouse National Recreation Trail. Fishing in area creeks or the North Fork Bitterroot; hunting for deer and elk in season. Campground can accommodate RVs or trailers to 25 feet.

name: Kid Gore Shelter
description: overnight shelter located on the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and coincident Long Trail

name: Camp Penacook Shelter
description: CAMP PENACOOK SHELTER (Campground)

name: WRIGHT CREEK
description: Wright Creek Camping Area sits along the southern flank of the North Umpqua River. This site is a perfect starting point to your North Umpqua adventures!

name: BEAVER CREEK
description: BEAVER CREEK

name: Tower Rock
description: Located along the banks of the Ohio River, Tower Rock Campground offers beautiful scenery and close proximity to water activities like fishing and boating. The 1/4 mile trail can be accessed near the boat launch.  Be aware this area is prone to flooding when river levels fluctuate.

name: Camp Run
description: Nestled along a Shenandoah Mountain drainage in Pendleton County, WV, Camp Run, which contains 9 campsites, provides an opportunity for primitive 1950's style camping that is popular with hunters. This campground operates on a first-come, first-served basis.

name: Falls Creek 998 (Trailhead And Campground)
description: FALLS CREEK 998 (TRAILHEAD AND CAMPGROUND) (Campground)

name: Madden Creek Campground
description: Madden Creek Campground - Dispersed Campground

name: WEST MAGNOLIA
description: Designated campsites along eight miles of Forest Roads. Roads are open seasonally. Check the Road Status Table before your visit. Camping is allowed in designated campsites only. There are no facilities of any kind. Motor Vehicle Use Maps display National Forest System (NFS) routes open to motorized travel. NOTE: The roads in this area are seasonal and are closed to motorized vehicles from November - May.

name: DIAMONDFIELD JACK CG
description: Diamond field Jack Campground and Picnic Area is located at the end of a paved road in Rock Creek. The campground is suitable for motor homes, trailers, and tent camping. This area is accessible year around. Campground amenities include drinking water, wheelchair accessible toilets, picnic tables, warming shelter, parking area, and fire rings. It is a winter play area from December through March. Pike Mountain and Eagle Trails (#239 and #243) are easy multi-use trails nearby.

name: Hoegees
description: Hoegees Trail Camp can be found by starting at the Chantry Flat Picnic Area and hiking along the Winter Creek Trail. The 2.2 mile shaded hike offers a wonderful view of lush pines, oaks, and other vegetation.Once you make it to the campground, you'll have the option to continue onto the Upper Winter Creek trail for a 4.85 miles loop with 1,000 feet of elevation gain. Another option is to connect to the Gabrielino Trail and continue on to Mt. Wilson.Amenities: 13Hike-in campsites- picnic tables and campfire rings/klamath stoves, no toilets, notrash receptacles, no piped water available.Seasonal stream water (treat before using). However, water flow may be low or non-existent due to reduced rainfall. Please bring enough water for cooking, cleaning, drinking, and extinguishing campfires. Pack In-Pack Out.Hiking: Access tothe Upper Winter CreekTrail and the Gabrielino National Recreation Trail.

name: Turkey Foot Campground
description: Turkey Foot Campground is located off Elsam Fork Road (Forest #345) along the banks of War Fork Creek in Jackson County. The gravel road into the campground is steep. There is a low water ford across the creek at the campground entrance. Each of the 15 primitive, first come, first served sites are equipped with a picnic table, fire ring, tent pad and lantern pole. There is no water, electricity or dump station available in the campground. A playfield with a horseshoe pit is located at the end of camping area alongside the creek. The area serves as a trailhead for the Turkey Foot Loop Trail system.

name: Aspen Basin
description: The Aspen Basin Campground is located adjacent to the very large parking area at Santa Fe Ski Basin. There are 10 units, Picnic tables, and fire rings. There is a vaulted toiletat the far west end of theparking lot. This campground is less developed than most, and primarily serves those who use it for an overnight stay before embarking on a backpack into the Pecos. There is ample space for trailer/RV camping, but no dump station is available. There is no potable water and no Campground Host. The entire area is very scenic, and NM 475 is also designated as the Santa Fe Scenic Byway. Because of the scenic quality and the easy access from Santa Fe, the area is very busy, especially in the summer and in the fall aspen viewing season.

name: Haw Creek Falls Cg
description: Surrounded by a beautiful mature hardwood forest, Haw Creek Falls Point of Interest is located on a small mountain stream with picturesque falls, rocks, and a bluff. The Big Piney Wild and Scenic River is nearby. There is also an accessible trail to the waterfalls.  The Ozark Highlands Trail goes through this point of interest.  The area is open all year. No fees for camping or day use. Camping allowed in designated sites. There is a low water bridge at the entrance to Haw Creek Falls. This area is subject to flash flooding. Visitors are responsible for monitoring conditions and taking precautionary measures. The removal of the gate does not indicate the area is always safe during changing weather conditions.

name: WILLOW CREEK
description: The Willow Creek Campground offers secluded tent and trailer sites in a large ponderosa pine and aspen stand. The campsites are located on the banks of Willow Creek and offers picnic tables, fire rings, and a two vault toilets. The campground is located roughly an hour southeast of Lakeview, Oregon. Visitors need to pack plenty of water as there is no potable water onsite.

name: LENA LAKE CAMPGROUND
description: This heavily used walk-in campground is accessed by hiking 3.5 miles on; Lena Lake Trail #810. This backcountry primitive camping area; is; located along the west-shore of Lena Lake a large 55 acre lake in the Hamma  drainage; at 1,800 feet elevation. There are two pit toilets available on the west and north shores. Camp in designated sites located on either side of the lake. This area is heavily impacted by high visitor use! Campers must be familiar with Leave No Trace principles. Pack out all trash, camp within developed sites, and respect other visitors. From the campground there is access to The Brothers Wilderness via The Brothers Trail #821 which ends at The Brothers Base Camp. Wilderness regulations apply within The Brothers Wilderness. View a; Lena Lake Campground vicinity map; (.pdf)

name: Indian Point Campground
description: Located on central Arizona's largest lake. Several miles of hiking and trails wind through the site. Indian Point offers easy lake access to the north side of Roosevelt Lake with a paved boat ramp. Dispersed camping is also available with a stay limit of 14 days. Rules and regulations are posted at bulletin board areas. Please read and observe. Pack it in pack it out. DO NOT ATTEMPT TO CROSS TONTO CREEK WHEN IT IS FLOWING.

name: Slate Creek Campground - Back Loop
description: Slate Creek Campground is located right near Painted Rocks lake and has 7 sites complete with picnic tables and fire rings, and a vault toilet. Campground can accommodate RV's or trailers to 25 feet.

name: Gold Creek Campground
description: This campground provides access to hiking, horseback riding, fishing and four-wheel driving. The site lies next to the southeastern boundary of the Fossil Ridge Wilderness Area. This natural area is a haven for hikers, backpackers and equestrians. (No mechanized or motorized vehicles are permitted within its boundaries.) Several alpine lakes lie near the campground and allow anglers to fish in the natural beauty of the Rocky Mountain highlands. The landscape is spruce/fir and aspen trees. This is bear country, must practice safe food storage techniques.

name: Black Kettle
description: BLACK KETTLE (Campground)

name: Quemado Lake - El Caso Cg #1
description: QUEMADO LAKE - EL CASO CG #1 (Campground)

name: Lake Creek
description: The Lake Creek Campground is located approximately 32 miles southwest of Libby off the West Fisher road. The campground has 4 sites all with tent pads, tables and fire rings and able to accommodate up to a 32' rd. There are also 4 dispersed campsites. Campground roads and parking spurs are gravel or native material. Amenities include potable water and vault toilets.

name: Cottonwood Campground
description: Cottonwood Campground offers 10 campsites with fire rings and a vault toilet for the minimalistic or rustic adventurer. Recommended trailer length not to exceed 28ft. Vault toilet is ADA accesible. There are no garbage services at this site, so please pack it in, pack it out!

name: EASTFORK
description: East Fork campground has 6 campsites right on the confluence of the East and South forks of the Salmon River. There is no water and no garbage services here, but there is a vault toilet available.

name: Misery Spring Cg
description: Providing panoramic views from Ray Ridge into the; Wenaha-Tucannon Wilderness. Misery Spring Campground offers hunting and hiking recreational opportunities. Please; Leave-No-Trace.

name: HERRING CREEK
description: Herring Creek Campground situated in a mixed conifer forest near Herring Creek. It is located on Forest Road 4N12; turn right onto Herring Creek Road (4N12) off of Highway 108, about 3 miles from the Summit Ranger Station. The campground is approximately 9 miles from the Summit Ranger Station. There are 7 sites; each site has a table and a fire ring. The main road and parking pads are dirt-surfaced. Potable water is not available. Toilets are vault. Please practice Leave No Trace and Pack it in, Pack it out principles.

name: Reservoir Creek
description: 2 primitive sites with picnic tables and fire rings. Campground has a vault toilet but no garbage services or water. Trailhead for trail #192 from the campground through the steep terrain of the Bitterroot Range.

name: CONRAD CROSSING
description: Conrad Crossing Campground features 8 camp units (2 on the river and 5 above the highway), drinking water (June-October), vault toilets, and a day use area. Please observe the Pack it In Pack it Out refuse policy. Attractions include historic Montana Trail, St. Joe Wild and Scenic River, fishing, and floating until mid June. Raft access.

name: Whitlock
description: A small, quiet camp amid large oaks and ponderosa pines.

name: Burrell'S Ford
description: Burrells Ford Campground is located on the Chattooga Wild and Scenic River near many miles of hiking trails and is open year round with no charge. The campground is a 0.25 mile walk from the parking lot. A vault toilet, picnic tables, and food storage lockers are available.

name: BIG BEAVER
description: A campground in the Main Boulder area on the Yellowstone District. Campground road not suitable for vehicles longer than 32ft.

name: Ponderosa Cove Cg
description: Ponderosa Cove greets group campers with shaded campsites close to scenic Stumpy Meadows Reservoir. The campground provides a pleasant destination for bird watching and nature viewing, in addition to activities at the lake.

name: BERRY CREEK CAMPGROUND
description: This disperse campground has picnic tables and campfire rings. At this campground, recreation activities include river/stream fishing, mountain biking, backpack/day hiking, horseback riding, cross-country skiing, and snowshoeing.

name: Buck Creek Horse Camp
description: BUCK CREEK HORSE CAMP (Horse Camp)

name: Ekalaka Park
description: Campground with 7 sites and two day use picnic sites near Ekalaka on the Ekalaka Hills Unit, Sioux Ranger District.  The Ekalaka Hills consist of scenic cliff drop-offs and cliff-edge views over the surrounding prairie, from Ponderosa pine savanna uplands. Accessible Facilities:ToiletTrash Pickup: NoFirewood: NoNo Reservations: This campground does not use a reservation system, it is managed on a first-come, first-served basis. There is a 14 day stay limit.Information:Sioux District OfficeBox 37, Main  FirstCamp Crook, SD 57724(605) 797-4432

name: SOUTH LAKE DISPERSED CAMP
description: At an elevation of 2,400 feet, this area offers dispersed camping along the northern edge of the lake. The lake is stocked periodically with rainbow trout. There is access for launching non-motorized boats. A vault toilet is provided but no potable water. It is also the eastern trailhead of the Pioneer-Indian Trail.

name: CHINA HAT
description: This campground is located near China Hat, a tall (6,573 ft. elevation), cone-shaped formation. The campground is shaded by lodgepole and ponderosa pine trees and lies in the heart of the East Fort Rock OHV Trail System. This campground is also a popular area for hunters during deer season. The campground has 13 designated campsites, with picnic tables and fire rings. There are 2 areas of adjoining sites that will accommodate small groups and large RVs. A vault toilet is located within the campground. China Hat Campground is operated and maintained for your enjoyment by Central Oregon Combined OHV Operations (a Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management Cooperative agreement), in partnership with Oregon Department of Parks and Recreation ATV Funds, and other user groups and volunteers.

name: South Fork
description: SOUTH FORK (Campground)

name: Lockridge Shelter
description: LOCKRIDGE SHELTER (Camping Area)

name: Whisky Falls
description: There are 14 campsites at this facility. No showers or RV hookups

name: Alder Thicket Cg
description: Welcome to the northern gateway into the Blues. This campground is located just off of Forest Service Road 40, which is just three miles into the Blue Mountains. Overgrown trees and tall Alder shrubbery will provide plenty of shade for Grouse, White- Tailed deer and yourself on hot summer days. Hiking trails are within five miles and the Clearwater Guard station is six miles from the Alder Thicket Campground.

name: Maple Grove Cg
description: Backcountry Campground accessed via the Baker Lake Trail.

name: Granite Creek
description: Located along Granite Creek, Granite Creek Campground has two loops containing 20 campsites. Fir trees provide a good amount of shade at campsites. Horses are not permited in the lower loop; however, the upper loop of the facility is horse-friendly and offers corrals. The campground provides vault toilets and each site has picnic tables.

name: Red Meadow Lake Campground
description: At an elevation of 5,500 feet, Red Meadow Campground has 6 campsites near Red Meadow Lake. Bring your own drinking water, a vault toilet is available.

name: Skyline Fc
description: SKYLINE FC (Campground)

name: OROFINO CAMPGROUND
description: This campground covers 3 acres in southwest Montana and is located approximately 13 miles southeast of Deerlodge on FS Road #82. The pavilion is first come, first serve and reservations are not needed for this site. There are 10 camping units available, with a recommendation that trailers do not exceed 22 feet. A picnic day use area is also available at this site, along with toilet however garbage services are not available for this site so please, pack it in, pack it out, and do not exceed the 16 day camping limit. Water is available at this site from a hand pump.

name: POTOSI CAMPGROUND
description: Potosi Campground located on the east side of the Tobacco Root Mountains with South Willow Creek running through the middle. There are 15 designated campsites, a picnic day-use area, vault toilets, and drinking water at this site. There are no garbage services, so pack it in and pack it out. We recommend trailer length does not exceed 22.

name: Big Foot Horse Camp
description: This horse trail is approximately 23.7 miles long and moderate in difficulty. Big Foot Horse Trail consists of four loops ranging in length from 5 to 11 miles. A ride of almost any desired length can be made by combinations of these loops. Most of the trails run parallel to roads, making it possible to enter the trail at any point.

name: McClure Campground
description: The McClure Campground is located on Highway 133, on the south side of McClure Pass. The historic town of Marble is nearby and the campground sits at the head of Lee Creek. Each campsites has a picnic table and fire ring/grill. This quiet campground is surrounded by aspen that provide excellent shade during the summer, and there are beaver ponds nearby for trout fishing.

name: CORRAL SPRINGS CAMPGROUND
description: For those seeking solitude and quiet, Corral Springs is the place. This quiet campground is located 15 minutes northwest of Chemult, Oregon. There are five campsites among; lodgepole pines, each with a picnic table and fire ring. There are also two vault toilets and an information board. A narrow creek meanders through the middle of the campground, fed by a spring that gurgles out of a Knoll. In the fall, Corral Springs is popular amongst hunters. In the summertime, this is an ideal campground for in relaxing in a primitive setting. June and July are heavy mosquito months so bring bug spray. There is no; potable water. Visitors need to pack plenty of water

name: North Fork Slate Creek
description: The North Fork Slate Creek Campground consists of five campsites, picnic tables and fire rings located at the confluence of Slate Creek and its North Fork. Hikers as well as mountain bikers can enjoy a number of loop trails in the area.  Parking is suitable for up to five vehicles. Small tent/travel trailers can be utilized as can self-contained pickup campers and motor homes.

name: Lockaby
description: CLOSED DUE TO RIVERSIDE FIRE Lockaby Campground is located next to the Wild and Scenic Clackamas River. It provides access to whitewater rafting, as well as a place to fish. Whether it is relaxation or recreation, there 's something for everyone at the campground.

name: Railroad Canyon
description: RAILROAD CANYON (Campground)

name: Stillwater Lake Campground
description: Upper Stillwater Lake Campground has 5 designated campsites, restroom, gravel boat launch, and day parking. The area has several hiking trails near by and the Stillwater River borders the campground.

name: Dairy Point Campground
description: Dairy Point Campground is located one hour 20 minutes south of Paisley, OR. This site borders a riparian area along Dairy Creek and has a diverse mix of ponderosa pines, willows, and grasses. This campground offers hand-pumped potable water, one vault toilet, and five camping sites with picnic tables and fire grates. It's a great location for destination camping, relaxing, and leisure. Please be respectful of surrounding private lands.

name: Pole Bridge Campground
description: POLE BRIDGE CAMPGROUND (Camping Area)

name: Trout Lakes
description: Trout Lakes contains 12primitive campsites and access roads within the campground. Sites are best suited for tent camping and small campers/camp trailers. Three lakes provide fishing opportunities amid a setting of quiet conifers and aspen. Summer’s quiet beauty turns to gold as autumn touches the aspen and rewards campers lingering in the area.Safety InformationAccess road to Trout Lakes is extremely hazardous when wet. This road is graveled from U.S. Highway 84 for three miles. The remainder is not graveled and is extremely slick and hazardous when wet. Monsoon rains make this road impassable. High clearance vehicle and four-wheel drive is recommended. Large RVs or camper trailers are allowed but not recommended because of the road.General Information:Be extremely cautious with fire and use only the fireplaces provided. Please do not cut down trees or shrubs; they provide natural scenery and shade-not firewood. Please do not carve on the trees. Carving leaves a wound where fungus can enter and kill the tree.Please do not deposit fish remains in the lakes and clean fish away from the water. Please wrap fish remains and other highly spoilage meats, food, etc., in small plastic bags, then in bread wrappers, and/or newspapers. Pack out all trash on your way out of the campground and fishing area.Please pick up litter around your campsite and pack it out with you. Also please read and comply with the posted regulations.Thank you for your help. Enjoy your visit!

name: Stratton View Shelter & Tent Area
